original: 祇園精舎の鐘の聲、諸行無常の響あり。
translation: The sound of the bell at Gion Shōjō proclaims the impermanence of all things.

original: 娑羅雙樹の花の色、盛者必衰のことわりをあらはす。
translation: The color of the娑羅雙樹 (sarushōju) flowers reveals the truth that all prosperity must decay.

original: おごれる人も久しからず、唯春の夜の夢のごとし。
translation: Those who are arrogant will not remain so long, for they are but dreams of a spring night.

original: 彼親王の御子、高親王無官無位にして、うせ給ひぬ。
translation: The prince’s son, the high-ranking prince, was given no title or rank and was left without official status.

original: 遠く異朝をとぶらへば、秦の趙高、漢の王莽、梁の周伊、唐の禄山、是等は皆舊主先皇の政にもしたがはず、樂みをきはめ、諫をおもひいれず、天下のみだれむ事をさとらずして、民間の愁る所をしらざりしかば、久からずして亡じし者ども也。
translation: Looking far back to other dynasties, such as Qin’s Zhao Gao, Han’s Wang Mang, Liang’s Zhou Yi, and Tang’s An Lushan, these men all once served under their former sovereigns. Yet, they sought pleasure and ignored advice, unaware of the chaos they would bring, and ignorant of the people’s suffering. Thus, they did not last long before perishing.

original: 國香より正盛に至る迄、六代は諸國の受領たりし
translation: From Kuniyoshi to Masamori, six generations served as governors of various provinces.

original: 其子鎭守府將軍義茂後には國香とあらたむ。
translation: His son, General of the Garrison, Yoshimori, was later known as Kuniyoshi.

original: たけき者も遂にほろびぬ、偏に風の前の塵に同じ。
translation: Even the mighty shall eventually fall, becoming but dust before the wind.

original: かども、殿上の仙籍をばいまだゆるされず。
translation: Yet, none of them were ever granted the privilege of the imperial court’s registry.

original: 近く本朝をうかがふに、承平の將門、天慶の純友、康和の義親、平治の信頼、此等はおごれる心もたけき事も皆とりどりにこそありしかども、まぢかくは六波羅の入道、前太政大臣平朝臣清盛公と申し人のありさま、傳へうけたまはるこそ心も詞も及ばれね。
translation: Looking closely at this era, such as the Heike of the Eihō period, the Zenshō of the Tenkō period, the Yoritsune of the Kōwa period, and the Nobuyori of the Heiji period, all of these men had their own arrogance and strength. However, none can compare to the six waves of the monk, the former Prime Minister, Lord Minamoto no Yoshitaka, whose deeds are passed down and whose heart and words are beyond comparison.

original: 其先祖を尋ぬれば、桓武天皇第五の皇子、一品式部卿葛原親王九代の後胤讃岐守正盛が孫、刑部卿忠盛朝臣の嫡男なり。
translation: Tracing back his ancestry, he was the fifth son of Emperor桓武 (Kammu), the ninth descendant of Prince葛原 (Kawahara), the grandson of Governor of讃岐 (Sanuki) Masamori, and the eldest son of Minister of Justice Tadamori.

original: 其御子高望の王の時始めて平の姓を給て、上總介になり給しより、忽に王氏を出て人臣につらなる。
translation: It was only during the reign of the high-ranking prince that the name "Heike" was bestowed, and he became the Governor of Shikoku. Suddenly, he left the royal family and became a minister.

original: 聟に執て、聲花にもてなされければ、それも五節に「播磨米はとくさか、むくの葉か、人のきらをみがくは。」とぞはやされける。
translation: Again, the Minister of the Imperial Court, Kiyomori, when he was ten years old, was left alone by his father, the Minister of the Imperial Court, Kiyomori, and was taken in by the Minister of the Imperial Court, Kiyomori, who was still the Governor of Harima Province.

original: 上皇御感のあまりに内の昇殿をゆるさる。
translation: Because of the Emperor's deep gratitude, he was permitted to ascend to the inner court.

original: 境節但馬國のあきたりけるを給にけり。
translation: The province of Butsuga was granted to him.

original: 又花山院前太政大臣忠雅公、いまだ十歳と申し時、父中納言忠宗卿におくれたてまつて孤にておはしけるを、故中御門藤中納言家成卿いまだ播磨守たりし時、
translation: At that time, when he was still the head of the Treasure Office, he was present at the festival, and they changed their rhythm and said, "Black and dark, a dark head. What kind of person is this?"

original: 末代いかゞあらんずらむ、おぼつかなしとぞ人申ける。
translation: In ancient times, it was customary, but it is no longer the case.

original: 感にあづかしうへは敢て罪科の沙汰もなかりけり。
translation: "Although it is said that he carried the sword to avoid disgrace, it is clear that he prepared a wooden sword in case of future litigation. It is indeed a serious matter. The preparation of a wooden sword instead of a real one is a strange thing. Also, the presence of a court attendant in the small garden is a custom of the warrior class. Moronobu is not at fault."

original: しかるを忠盛備前守たりし時、鳥羽院の御願得長壽院を造進して三十三間の御堂をたて、一千一體の御佛をすゑ奉る。
translation: At that time, when Moronobu was the Governor of Bizen Province, he built the Longevity Temple at the request of the Imperial Court of Toba, constructing a hall thirty-three ken long and enshrining one thousand one Buddhist statues.

original: しかるべしとて、其刀をめし出して叡覽あれば、上は鞘卷のくろくぬりたりけるが、中は木刀に銀薄をぞおしたりける。
translation: He stated, "First, the reason for the attendant's presence at the small garden is that he was not aware of it. However, recently, there were rumors that people were gathering, and in order to help him with his disgrace, he secretly came to the palace without Moronobu's knowledge. If there is still any fault, should he be punished? Next, regarding the sword, it was entrusted to the head of the palace attendants. Should he be blamed for the truth of the sword?"

original: 陳じ申けるは、「まづ郎從小庭に祗候の由、全く覺悟つかまつらず。但し、近日人々あひたくまるゝ旨子細ある歟の間、年來の家人、事をつたへきくかによて其恥をたすけむが爲に、忠盛にしられずして竊に參候の條力及ざる次第なり。若し猶其咎あるべくば、彼身をめし進ずべき歟。次に刀の事、主殿司に預け置をはぬ。是をめし出され刀の實否について咎の左右あるべき歟。」と申。
translation: As expected, the festival ended, and the courtiers said, "It is a violation of the established rules for a man to carry a sword to a public banquet, to be given weapons, and to enter and exit the palace. However, Moronobu, the court official, is either called a court attendant or is placed in the small garden of the palace with common soldiers, or has his sword laid horizontally at the festival seat. These two violations are unprecedented. The matter is serious. The punishment should be severe. The Emperor should issue an imperial decree to dismiss him from his post."

original: 案のごとく五節はてにしかば、殿上人一同に申されけるは、「夫雄劍を帶して公宴に列し、兵仗を給て、宮中を出入するはみな格式の禮をまもる綸命よしある先規なり。しかるを忠盛朝臣或は相傳の郎從と號して布衣の兵を殿上の小庭にめしおき、或は腰の刀を横へさいて節繪の座につらなる。兩條希代いまだきかざる狼藉なり。事既に重疊せり。罪科尤ものがれがたし。早く御札をけづて闕官停任せらるべき由」おの／＼訴へ申されければ、上皇大に驚きおぼしめし、忠盛をめして御尋あり。
translation: What will be the case in later generations? People say it is uncertain.

original: 上古には加樣にありしかども事いでこず。
translation: He was taken in as a son-in-law and was treated with great care, and they also said at the festival, "Harima rice is a special kind, the leaves of the plant, the person who polishes the mirror."

original: 勸賞には闕國を給ふべき由仰下されける。
translation: It was decreed that the province of Kōkoku be given as a reward.

original: 「當座の恥辱をのがれん爲に刀を帶する由あらはすといへども、後日の訴訟を存知して、木刀を帶しける用意のほどこそ神妙なれ。弓箭に携らむ者のはかりごとは尤かうこそあらまほしけれ。兼ては又郎從小庭に祗候の條且は武士の郎等のならひなり。忠盛が咎にあらず。」とて却て叡
translation: Thus, the sword was presented to the Emperor for inspection, and it was found that the scabbard was blackened, but inside was a wooden sword with a thin layer of silver.

original: 貫首以下あやしみをなし、「うつぼ柱よりうち、鈴の綱のへんに布衣の者の候ふはなにものぞ。狼藉なり。罷出よ。」と、六位をもていはせければ、家貞申けるは「相傳の主、備前守殿今夜闇討にせられ給べき由承候あひだ、其ならむ樣を見むと
translation: The head of the attendants, suspecting something, said, "This person, coming from the pillar of the eel, appears at the edge of the bell rope. Who is this person in plain clothes? This is disorder. Leave at once!" and ordered him to leave, even granting him the rank of sixth grade.

original: 薄青の狩衣の下に萠黄威の腹卷をき、弦袋つけたる太刀脇はさんで、殿上の小庭に畏てぞ候ける。
translation: He wore a hunting coat of light blue with a yellow sash wrapped around his waist, and a sword with a string bag fastened at his side, standing in the small garden of the palace.

original: 其上忠盛の郎等もとは一門たりし木工助平貞光が孫しんの三郎太夫家房が子、左兵衞尉家貞といふ者ありけり。
translation: Among the attendants of Moronobu were the descendants of the same family, the woodworker Kiyotada, grandson of Kiyomori, the third son of the house of Kiyomori, known as Sadayori.

original: 諸人目をすましけり。
translation: The people present looked in astonishment.

original: 忠盛御前のめしにまはれければ、人々拍子をかへて「伊勢平氏はすがめなりけり。」とぞはやされける。
translation: So, he remained, and that night's assassination did not take place.

original: 」とて畏て候ければ、是等をよしなしとやおもはれけん、其夜の闇討なかりけり。
translation: "You should not leave."

original: えこそ罷出まじけれ。
translation: Thus, he remained.

original: 雲の上人是を嫉み、同き年の十一月廿三日、五節豐明の節會の夜、忠盛を闇討にせむとぞ擬せられける。
translation: The monk in the clouds, jealous of this, planned to assassinate Moronobu in the dark during the night of the festival of the fifth month on the twenty-third day of the same year.

original: 忠盛是を傳へ聞て、「われ右筆の身にあらず、武勇の家に生れて、今不慮の恥にあはむ事、家の爲、身の爲、こゝろうかるべし。せむずるところ、身を全して君に仕といふ本文あり。」とて、兼て用意をいたす。
translation: Upon hearing of this, Moronobu said, "I am not a scribe, but born into a family of warriors. To suffer an unexpected disgrace now would be a shame for my family and myself. The original purpose of my service is to preserve my life and serve my lord."

original: 參内のはじめより大なる鞘卷を用意して束帶のしたにしどけなげにさし、火のほのくらき方にむかて、やはら、此刀をぬき出し、鬢にひきあてられけるが、氷などの樣にぞみえける。
translation: From the beginning of his entry, he prepared a large scabbard, fastening it loosely to his belt, and facing the dim glow of fire, he drew the sword, and it appeared as if it were made of ice.

original: 忠盛三十六にて始て昇殿す。
translation: Moronobu, at the age of thirty-six, first ascended to the inner court.

original: 供養は天承元年三月十三日なり。
translation: The offering was made on the thirteenth day of the third month in the first year of the Tenshō era.

original: 其人いまだ藏人頭なりし時、五節にまはれければ、それも拍子をかへて、「あなくろ／＼、くろき頭かな。いかなる人のうるしぬりけむ。」とぞはやされける。
translation: Because his face was so dark, those who saw him called him the Black General.

original: あまりに色のくろかりければ、見る人黒帥とぞ申ける。
translation: At the festival, it was said, "White paper, light ink, the top of the scroll, the brush with the picture of the drum painted on it," and so on, and the person who said this was the Governor of the Province of Tō, Kiyomori.

original: て、かくて候。
translation: Sadayori replied, "I have been informed that Lord Moronobu, the Governor of Bizen, is to be assassinated in the dark tonight, and I came to see if that is indeed the case."

original: 其うへ忠盛目のすがまれたりければ、加樣にはやされけり。
translation: Though these people were descendants of Emperor Kōryō, they were not of noble lineage, and because they lived in Ise Province, they were called the Ise Heike in accordance with the customs of that province.

original: いかにすべき樣もなくして、御遊もいまだをはらざるに、竊に罷出らるとて、よこたへさされたりける刀をば紫宸殿の御後にして、かたへの殿上人のみられける所にて、主殿司をめしてあづけ置てぞ出られける。
translation: Because Moronobu's eyes were fixed upon them, they were praised.

original: 家貞待うけたてまつて、「さていかゞ候つる。」と申ければ、かくともいはまほしう思はれけれども、いひつるものならば、殿上までもやがてきりのぼらんずる者にてある間、「別の事もなし。」とぞ答られける。
translation: Without knowing what to do, while the Emperor had not yet finished his meal, they secretly left, and the sword that had been laid horizontally was placed behind the Purple宸 Hall, in the place where only the courtiers could be seen, and the head of the palace attendants was entrusted with it, and they left.

original: 此人々はかけまくもかたじけなく柏原天皇の御末とは申ながら、中比は都の住居もうと／＼しく、地下にのみ振舞なて伊勢國に住國ふかかりしかば、其國の器に事よせて、伊勢平氏とぞ申ける。
translation: Because he was serving at the banquet of Moronobu, the people changed their rhythm and said, "The Ise Heike are like crows."

original: 五節には、「白薄樣、こぜむじの紙、卷上の筆、鞆繪ゑがいたる筆の軸」なんどさま％＼面白き事をのみこそうたひまはるるに、中比太宰權帥季仲卿といふ人ありけり。
translation: Sadayori, waiting to receive him, said, "So, what is the situation?" and he replied, "If I had said that, I would have thought it was not necessary, but if I had to say something, I would have to say that, even though it would be a disgrace to ascend to the court, it would be necessary to do so. However, there is no other matter."

original: うちたひらげ、勳功一にあらず、恩賞是おもかるべしとて、次の年正三位に敍せられ、うちつゞき、宰相、衞府督、檢非違使別當、中納言、大納言に歴あがて、剰へ丞相の位にいたり、左右を歴ずして内大臣より太政大臣從一位にあがる。
translation: He was the first to suppress the rebels, and thus, he was highly commended and received great rewards. In the following year, he was promoted to the rank of the First Class, and continued to rise through the ranks of Chancellor, Commander of the Imperial Guards, Chief of the Office of the Inspector General, Minister of the Left, Minister of the Right, and eventually reached the position of Chancellor, serving on both sides and rising from Minister of the Left to Chief Minister, the highest rank of the First Class.

original: 次に平治元年十二月、信頼卿が謀反の時、御方にて賊徒を
translation: Next, in the twelfth month of Heiji 1, when the Minister of the Left, Tadamasa, conspired against the Emperor, he was ordered to suppress the rebels.

original: 其子どもは諸衞の佐になり、昇殿せしに殿上のまじはりを人きらふに及ばず。
translation: His children became attendants of the court, but when they were allowed to ascend the palace, they could not discern the customs of the court.

original: されば則闕の官とも名付たり。
translation: Therefore, the office was also called the "vacant office."

original: 「太政大臣は一人に師範として四海に儀刑せり。國を治め、道を論じ、陰陽をやはらげをさむ。其人にあらずば即ち闕けよ。」といへり。
translation: "The Chief Minister is the only one who serves as a model for the entire country. He governs the nation, discusses the way, and harmonizes the yin and yang. If there is no such person, then the state is in disorder." Thus it was said.

original: 子孫の官途も龍の雲に上るよりは猶すみやかなり。
translation: The official career of his descendants surpassed even the rising of the dragon's cloud.

original: 偏に執政の臣のごとし。
translation: He was a prime minister and chief administrator.

original: 牛車輦車の宣旨を蒙て、のりながら宮中を出入す。
translation: He was granted permission to ride in a cow cart and a palanquin, and could enter and exit the palace while riding.

original: にるを友とかやの風情に忠盛もすいたりければ、かの女房も優なりけり。
translation: Because Tadamasa was known for his friendship and manner, that concubine was also refined.

original: 薩摩守忠度の母、是なり。
translation: This was the mother of Sadamori.

original: 九代の先蹤をこえ給ふこそ目出けれ。
translation: It was a great achievement to surpass the lineage of nine generations.

original: かくて忠盛刑部卿になて、仁平三年正月十五日歳五十八にてうせにき。
translation: Thus, Tadamasa became Minister of Justice, and on the fifteenth day of the first month of the year Renpō 3, he died at the age of fifty-eight.

original: と申たりければ、御感ありけり。
translation: When he said this, the Emperor was moved.

original: とよみたりければ、いとゞあさからずぞおもはれける。
translation: When she said this, it was greatly admired.

original: 忠盛又仙洞に最愛の女房をもてかよはれけるが、ある時、其女房のつぼねに、つまに月出したる扇をわすれて出られたりければ、かたへの女房たち「是はいづくよりの月影ぞや。出どころおぼつかなし。」などわらひあはれければ、彼女房、雲井よりたゞもりきたる月なれば、おぼろげにてはいはじとぞ思ふ。
translation: Tadamasa had a beloved concubine at Zen-dō. One day, the concubine forgot to bring a fan with a moon design and went out. The other concubines laughed and said, "Where did this moonlight come from? It's unclear." She replied, thinking that the moonlight came from the cloud well at Un-no, and was therefore indistinct.

original: 其比、忠盛、備前國より都へのぼりたりけるに、鳥羽院「明石浦はいかに。」と御尋ありければ、あり明の月もあかしのうら風に、浪ばかりこそよると見えしか。
translation: At that time, Tadamasa ascended from Bizen Province to the capital. When the Emperor asked, "What is the situation at Akashi Bay?" the moonlight reflected on the clear waters, and it seemed only the waves were beautiful.

original: 大將にあらね共、兵仗をたまはて隨身をめし具す。
translation: Although he was not the commander-in-chief, he was given military authority and was provided with attendants.

original: 保元々年七月に宇治の左府代をみだり給し時、安藝守とて御方にて勳功ありしかば、播磨守にうつて同三年太宰大貳になる。
translation: In the seventh month of the first year of Hōgen, when he was given the position of Left Minister's Deputy at Uji in an improper manner, because he had served as Governor of Aki and had been commended by the Emperor, he was transferred to Governor of Harima and in the same year became Chief Administrator of the Tōdai.

original: 清盛嫡男たるによてその迹をつぐ。
translation: He inherited the position because he was the eldest son of Kiyomori.

original: 其故にや吉事のみうちつゞいて太政大臣まできはめ給へり。
translation: Therefore, the good fortune continued and he was elevated to the position of Chief Minister.

original: 其故は、古へ清盛公、いまだ安藝守たりし時、伊勢の海より船にて熊野へまゐられけるに、大きなる鱸の船にをどり入たりけるを、先達申けるは、「是は權現の御利生なり。いそぎまゐるべし。」と申ければ、清盛のたまひけるは、「昔、周の武王の船にこそ白魚は躍入たりけるなれ。是吉事なり。」とて、さばかり十戒をたもちて、精進潔齋の道なれども、調味して家の子、侍ともにくはせられけり。
translation: The reason for this was that in ancient times, when Kiyomori was still Governor of Aki, he traveled by boat from the sea of Ise to Kumano. He saw a large crucian carp jump into his boat. The guide said, "This is a blessing from the deity. You should hurry to pay your respects." Kiyomori replied, "In ancient times, the White Fish jumped into the boat of King Wu of Zhou. This is a good omen." Thus, he carried ten precepts, and although he followed the path of purification and fasting, he prepared seasoned food for his family and servants.

original: 平家かやうに繁昌せられけるも熊野權現の御利生とぞきこえし。
translation: The prosperity of the Heike was said to be due to the blessings of the Kumano Gongen.

original: この歌は金葉集にぞ入られける。
translation: This poem was included in the Kankashū.

original: 其人ならではけがすべき官ならねども、一天四海を掌の内ににぎられしうへは子細に及ばず。
translation: Although this position could only be held by a suitable person, it was not fully within the control of the holder to manage the entire world and the four seas.

original: 世のあまねく仰げる事ふる雨の國土をうるほすに同じ。
translation: The world universally praises things, just as the rain nourishes the land.

original: 人のしたがひつく事吹風の草木をなびかすがごとし。
translation: The actions of people spread like the wind, causing grass and trees to sway.

original: されば入道相國のこしうと、平大納言時忠卿ののたまひけるは「此一門にあらざらむ人は皆人非人なるべし。」とぞのたまひける。
translation: Therefore, the former Minister of the Monastic Order, the Lord of Rokuhara, and the Minister of the Left, Tadamasa, said, "Those who are not of this lineage are surely neither human nor beast."

original: 六波羅殿の御一家の君達といひてしかば、花族も英雄も面をむかへ肩をならぶる人なし。
translation: Thus, when speaking of the family of the Lord of Rokuhara, there is no one among the noble houses or heroes who would not face each other and stand side by side.

original: 衣文のかきやう烏帽子のため樣よりはじめて何事も六波羅樣といひてければ、一天四海の人皆是をまなぶ。
translation: From the way of dressing, the style of the cap, and everything else, they began to call them the Rokuhara style, and so all people across the heavens and seas followed this example.

original: 又いかなる賢王聖主の御政も攝政關白の御成敗も世にあまされたるいたづら者などの、人のきかぬ處にてなにとなうそしり傾け申事は常の習なれども、此禪門世ざかりの程は聊いるかせにも申者なし。
translation: Again, it is customary for the wise kings and holy sovereigns, the decisions of regents and chancellors, and the deeds of those who have long been respected by the world, to be spoken of in places where people do not listen, but in this age of Zen, there is no one who would dare to speak of such things.

original: 其故は入道相國のはかりごとに十四五六の童部を三百人そろへて、髮をかぶろにきりまはし、あかき直垂をきせて、めしつかはれけるが、京中にみち／＼て、往反しけり。
translation: The reason for this is that the Lord of Rokuhara, the Monastic Minister, had arranged for fifteen to sixteen boys, a total of three hundred, to have their hair cut and to wear bright robes, and they went back and forth throughout Kyoto.

original: 禁門を出入すといへども姓名を尋らるゝに及ばず、京師の長吏これが為に目を側むとみえたり。
translation: Although they entered and exited the imperial gate, they were not asked for their names, and the officials of the capital seemed to have turned their eyes away for this reason.

original: かゝりしかば、いかなる人も相構へて其ゆかりにむすぼほれんとぞしける。
translation: Thus, no matter who they were, all people sought to be connected to this lineage.

original: 角て清盛公、仁安三年十一月十一日歳五十一にて病にをかされ、存命の爲に忽に出家入道す。
translation: Minamoto no Tadamasa, on the eleventh day of the eleventh month in the third year of the Ren-an era, at the age of fifty-one, fell ill and, in order to preserve his life, suddenly renounced the world and entered the monastic life.

original: 法名は淨海とこそなのられけれ。
translation: His posthumous name was given as Jōkai.

original: 其しるしにや、宿病たちどころにいえて、天命を全す。
translation: Thus, as a sign, his long-standing illness was immediately cured, and he completed his fate under heaven.

original: されば目に見、心に知るといへども、詞にあらはれて申者なし。
translation: Thus, although one might see it with one's eyes and know it with one's heart, there was no one who dared to express it in words.

original: 自ら平家の事あしざまに申者あれば、一人きゝ出さぬほどこそありけれ、餘黨に觸廻して、其家に亂入し資材雜具を追捕し、其奴を搦とて、六波羅へゐてまゐる。
translation: Because there were people who spoke ill of the Minamoto family, there was not a single person who did not hear of it; thus, they spread among the remnants, entered the house, seized the property and belongings, captured the servants, and went to Rokuhara.

original: 六波羅殿の禿と云ひてしかば、道をすぐる馬車もよぎてぞ、通りける。
translation: Because they were called the Rokuhara bald ones, even carriages and horses passed by without stopping.

original: 軒騎群集して門前市をなす。
translation: Gold from Yangzhou, pearls from Jingzhou, silk from Wu, brocade from Shu River—there is not a single one of the seven treasures or ten thousand precious things missing.

original: 又安藝國嚴島の内侍が腹に一人おはせしは、後白河の法皇へまゐらせたまひて女御のやうにてぞましましける。
translation: Another was the daughter of the attendant of the Lady of the Six-Stripe Palace, who was sent to the Emperor Go-Shirakawa as a concubine.

original: 楊州の金、荊州の珠、呉郡の綾、蜀江の錦、七珍萬寶一として闕たる事なし。
translation: The foundations of halls for poetry and dance, and the playthings of fish, dragons, jugs, and horses—perhaps even the imperial palace or the fairy cave would not surpass this.

original: これは花山院殿に上臈女房にて廊の御方とぞ申ける。
translation: Japan's Autumn Tsushima is but sixty-six provinces, the lands of the Heike clan are more than thirty provinces, already surpassing half the country.

original: 其外九條院の雜仕常葉が腹に一人。
translation: Another was the daughter of the attendant of the Lady of the Six-Stripe Palace, who was called the Lady of the Corridor.

original: 其外莊園田畠いくらといふ數をしらず。
translation: Rich in silks and luxuries, like a blooming flower in the court.

original: 日本秋津島は纔に六十六箇國、平家知行の國三十餘箇國、既に半國にこえたり。
translation: In addition, the number of estates and fields is unknown.

original: 昔奈良の御門の御時、神龜五年、朝家に中衞の大將をはじめおかれ、大同四年に中衞を近衞と改られしよりこのかた、兄弟左右に相並事僅に三四箇度なり。
translation: In the days of the Nara gate, in the seventh year of the Kankō era, the imperial court appointed a Chief of the Middle Guard. From the fourth year of the Daitō era, when the Middle Guard was renamed the Near Guard, until now, there have been only a few instances—only three or four—where brothers served on the left and right sides of the court.

original: 文徳天皇の御時は左に良房右大臣左大將、右に良相、大納言の右大將、是は閑院の左大臣冬嗣の御子なり。
translation: In the reign of Emperor Mutsu, on the left was Rōhō, the Right Minister and Left Great General, and on the right was Rōsō, the Right Great General and Minister of the Interior. These were the sons of the Left Minister, Shōshi, of the Ikan-in.

original: 朱雀院の御宇には左に實頼、小野宮殿、右に師輔、九條殿、貞信公の御子なり。
translation: In the reign of Emperor Kōkō, on the left was Shikira, the Small野 Palace, and on the right was Shisō, the Kujō Palace. These were the sons of the Minister of the Interior,贞信公.

original: 一人は櫻町の中納言重教卿の北の方にておはすべかりしが、八歳の時約束ばかりにて平治の亂以後ひきちがへられ、花山院の左大臣殿の御臺盤所にならせ給て君達あまたましましけり。
translation: One of them was the wife of the Minister of the Interior, Shigekatsu, of the Sakura-machi. But when she was eight years old, she was promised in marriage, but after the Heiji Rebellion, the arrangement changed, and she was placed in the residence of the Left Minister of the Hana-yama Palace, and many of the courtiers were her attendants.

original: 抑この重教卿を櫻町の中納言と申ける事はすぐれて心數奇給へる人にて、つねは吉野山をこひ、町に櫻をうゑならべ、其内に屋を立て、すみたまひしかば、來る年の春ごとに、みる人櫻町とぞ申ける。
translation: The reason this Shigekatsu was called the Minister of the Interior of Sakura-machi was that he was a man of strange fortune. He always loved the Yoshino Mountains and arranged cherry blossoms in the town, building a house within them. Because he stayed there, people began to call the place "Sakura-machi" every spring.

original: 一人は普賢寺殿の北の政所にならせ給ふ。
translation: One of them was made the Lady of the Northern Court of the Priest of the Bodhisattva Hall.

original: 高倉院御在位の時御母代とて准三后の宣旨をかうぶり、白河殿とておもき人にてましましけり。
translation: During the reign of the Emperor at Takakura, she served as the mother-in-law to the emperor, and was granted the title of the quasi-third consort, and was regarded as a person of great importance.

original: 一人は六條の攝政殿の北政所にならせ給ふ。
translation: One of them was made the Lady of the Northern Court of the Regent of the Six-Stripe Palace.

original: 入道相國の御娘なるうへ、天下の國母にてましましければとかう申におよばず。
translation: Because she was the daughter of the retired emperor, and was the mother of the country, she was called by a title beyond that of the imperial consort.

original: 王子御誕生ありて皇太子に立ち、位につかせ給しかば、院號かうぶらせ給ひて、建禮門院とぞ申ける。
translation: When the prince was born and became the crown prince, he was given a position, and the imperial title was bestowed upon him, and he was called the Lady of the Gate of Reason.

original: 一人は后にたゝせ給ふ。
translation: One of them was later given in marriage.

original: 一人は冷泉大納言隆房卿の北方。
translation: One of them was made the Lady of the Northern Court of the Minister of the Interior, Rikyū.

original: 一人は七條修理大夫信隆卿に相具し給へり。
translation: One of them was made the Lady of the Northern Court of the Minister of Works, Shinryō.

original: 綺羅充滿して、堂上花の如し。
translation: A crowd of horses and carriages gathered, forming a market at the gate.

original: 君も賢王にてましませば神も神徳を輝かし、花も心ありければ、二十日の齡をたもちけり。
translation: Because he was a wise king, the gods shone with their virtue, and the flowers, too, had feelings, so he lived to be twenty days old.

original: 櫻はさいて七箇日にちるを、名殘を惜み天照御神に祈申されければ、三七日迄名殘ありけり。
translation: The cherry blossoms bloomed for seven days, but because he prayed to the sun goddess Amaterasu out of longing, they bloomed for twenty-one days.

original: 是皆攝
translation: These were all the sons of officials.

original: 其外御娘八人おはしき。
translation: In addition, there were eight daughters.

original: 殿上の交をだにきらはれし人の子孫にて禁色雜袍をゆり、綾羅錦繍を身にまとひ、大臣大將になて、兄弟、左右に相並事、末代とはいひながら不思議なりし事どもなり。
translation: The descendants of those who were even disliked by the court, wearing imperial robes and fine silks, and rising to the ranks of minister and general, with brothers serving on the left and right, are strange things, though not of the last generation.

original: 祿の臣の御子息、凡人にとりては其例なし。
translation: The sons of officials, for ordinary people, is not an example to follow.

original: 二條院の御宇には左に基房、松殿、右に兼實、月輪殿、法性寺殿の御子なり。
translation: In the reign of Emperor Nijō, on the left was Kihō, the Pine Palace, and on the right was Kanemitsu, the Moon Wheel Palace. These were the sons of the Minister of the Interior, Hōjō-ji.

original: 皆とり／＼に幸給へり。
translation: All of them were married to noble families.

original: 吾身の榮花を極るのみならず、一門共に繁昌して、嫡子重盛、内大臣の左大將、次男宗盛、中納言の右大將、三男知盛、三位中將、嫡孫維盛、四位少將、すべて一門の公卿十六人、殿上人三十餘人、諸國の受領、衞府、諸司、都合六十餘人なり。
translation: Not only did I reach the peak of my glory, but my entire family flourished together. The eldest son, Shigemasa, was the Left Great General and Minister of the Interior; the second son, Munemasa, was the Right Great General and Minister of the Interior; the third son, Shigekatsu, was the Middle General of the Third Rank; the eldest grandson, Moromasa, was the Young General of the Fourth Rank. Altogether, there were sixteen nobles of the family in the court, more than thirty courtiers, and over sixty officials in charge of various provinces, guards, and offices.

original: 世にはまた人なくぞ見えられける。
translation: There was no one else in the world.

original: 御冷泉院の御時は、左に教通、大二條殿、右に頼宗、堀河殿、御堂の關白の御子なり。
translation: In the reign of Emperor Cold Spring, on the left was Kōtō, the Great Second Kujō Palace, and on the right was Yorizō, the堀 River Palace. These were the sons of the Chancellor of the御堂.

original: たとへば其比都に聞えたる白拍子の上手、祇王祇女とて兄弟あり、とぢといふ白拍子が娘なり。
translation: For example, there was a master of the white dance in the province of Izu, and he had a brother and sister, the latter being the daughter of a woman named Tōji.

original: 羨む者共は「あなめでたの祇王御前が幸や。おなじあそび女とならば、誰もみなあの樣でこそありたけれ。いかさま是は祇といふ文字を名についてかくはめでたきやらん。いざ我等もついて見む。」とて或は祇一と付き、祇二と付き、或は祗福祗徳などいふ者も有けり。
translation: Those who envied her said, "How fortunate is Jōō! If we were all as fortunate as she is, we would all be like her. How wonderful it is that her name is Jō! Let us go and see for ourselves." So some followed her as Jōichirō, Jōni, and others named Jōfuku, Jōtokku, and so on.

original: 一人參らむはあまりにものうしとて妹の祇女をも相具しけり。
translation: Jōō thought, "What is this? I have done nothing wrong, but I have been treated this way. How can I do anything?" She was so sad that tears fell from her eyes.

original: 其後入道は祇王が心の内をも知たまはず、「いかに其後何事かある。さては佛御前があまりにつれ／＼げに見ゆるに、今樣一つ歌へかし。」とのたまへば、祇王參る程では、ともかうも入道殿の仰をば背くまじと思ひければ、落つる涙をおさへて、今樣一つぞ歌うたる。
translation: When she sang it twice, all the people present, from the Minister of the Buddha's Way to the court officials, the imperial court, and the attendants, were moved to tears.

original: 縱ひ都を出さるとも、我御前たちは年若ければ、如何ならん岩木のはざまにても過さん事安かるべし。
translation: Only live in the capital.

original: 年老い衰へたる母都の外へぞ出されんずらん。
translation: This is the way of filial piety for this life and the next.

original: 習はぬ旅の住居こそかねて思ふも悲しけれ。
translation: Jōō thought this was a good way, but she was ashamed to disobey her parents, so she decided to leave again.

original: 唯我を都の内にて住果させよ。
translation: She also took her sister, Jōjo, with her.

original: 其ぞ今生後生の孝養と思はむずる。
translation: In addition to two white dancers, they all got on a single carriage and went to the West Eight Streets.

original: 」といへば、祇王うしと思し道なれども、親の命を背かじと、なく／＼又出立ける心の中こそ無慚なれ。
translation: They were not allowed to enter the place where they had been summoned, so they were placed in a room far away.

original: 祇王とう／＼罷出で
translation: Hō said, "How can I do that? If all of us are summoned, we will be very happy. But if only Jōō is summoned, it will be very embarrassing for her. If I am to leave, I will do so immediately."

original: よ。
translation: The Minister said, "Why should there be such a ceremony? Jōō should be summoned."

original: 」と御使かさねて三度までこそ立てられけれ。
translation: Jōō had already planned this, but she did not think it would be so soon.

original: 祇王もとよりおもひ設けたる道なれども、さすがに昨日今日とは思よらず。
translation: While she was hurrying to leave, she wiped her hands, swept away the dust, and prepared to leave, but she was very sad.

original: いそぎ出べき由頻にのたまふ間、はき拭ひ、塵ひろはせ、見苦しき物共とりしたためて出づべきにこそ定まりけれ。
translation: It is a sad custom to part ways under the same tree and by the same stream.

original: 一樹の陰に宿り合ひ、同じ流をむすぶだに別はかなしき習ぞかし。
translation: Especially since she had lived there for three years, it was very sad, and tears fell from her eyes.

original: まして此三年が間住なれし處なれば、名殘もをしう悲しくて、かひなき涙ぞこぼれける。
translation: But if there was no need for this, Jōō would have already left, but she thought of the traces left behind and wrote a song on the shoji screen.

original: 入道相國、一天四海をたなごゝろのうちににぎりたまひし間、世のそしりをもはばからず、人の嘲りをもかへり見ず、不思議の事をのみし給へり。
translation: While the Minister of the Buddha's Way was in full control of the heavens and the seas, he paid no heed to the world's criticism, nor did he look back at people's mockery, but only pursued strange and unusual things.

original: かくて今年も暮れぬ。
translation: In the spring of the following year, the Minister of the Buddha's Way sent a messenger to Jōō, saying, "What has happened since then?

original: あくる春の比、入道相國、祇王が許へ使者を立てて、「いかに其後何事
translation: Since Hō has been so eager to see you, come and sing the song and dance to comfort her."

original: 姉の祇王を入道相國最愛せられければ、是によて妹の祇女をも世の人もてなす事なのめならず。
translation: Since the Minister of the Buddha's Way loved his sister, Jōō, so it was not strange that the world also treated his sister, Jōjo, with great care.

original: 母とぢにもよき屋つくてとらせ、毎月百石百貫をおくられければ、家内富貴してたのしい事なのめならず。
translation: She was given a fine house, and every month, a hundred koku of rice and a hundred kan of silver were given to her, so her household became wealthy and happy.

original: 抑我朝に白拍子のはじまりける事は、昔鳥羽院の御宇に島の千歳和歌の前とてこれら二人がまひいだしたりけるなり。
translation: As for the origin of the white dance in our country, it is said that in the reign of Emperor Torihiko, these two people were in love, and they were together in the festival of the thousand-year song.

original: 始めは水干に立烏帽子、白鞘卷をさいて、舞ひければ、男舞とぞ申ける。
translation: At first, they wore a water-dry robe and a black hat, and carried a white scabbard, and danced, and this was called the male dance.

original: 入道「など祇王は返事はせぬぞ。參るまじいか。參るまじくば、其樣を申せ。淨海もはからふ旨あり。」とぞ宣ひける。
translation: The relationship between men and women is not something that begins in this life.

original: 祇王さればとて今更人に對面してあそびたはぶるべきにもあらねば、文を取入るゝ事もなく、まして使にあひしらふ迄もなかりけり。
translation: Even so, she was very sad and only cried.

original: 夕日の影の西の山の端に隱るゝを見ても、日の入給ふ所は西方淨土にてあんなり。
translation: It is not right to rely on the young.

original: かくて春過ぎ夏闌ぬ、秋の初風吹きぬれば、星合の空をながめつゝ、天のと渡る梶の葉に思ふ事かく比なれや。
translation: This time, if I fall into the hell, it will be hard to rise again, even after many lives.

original: 母とぢ是をみて若き娘どもだに樣を替る世中に年老い衰へたる母白髮をつけても何にかはせ
translation: Thinking of the things I have, I think that the world's happiness is like a dream. It is not worth it to be happy and prosperous.

original: むとて四十五にて髮を剃り、二人の娘諸共に一向專修に念佛して、ひとへに後世をぞ願ひける。
translation: It is hard to get a human body, and it is hard to meet the Buddhist teachings.

original: 」とさめざめとかき口説ければ、祇王なみだをおさへて「げにもさやうにさぶらはゞ五逆罪疑なし。さらば自害は思ひ止まり候ひぬ。かくて都にあるならば、又うき目をも見むずらん。今は都の外へ出でん。」とて祇王二十一にて尼になり、嵯峨野の奧なる山里に柴の庵をひきむすび念佛してこそ居たりけれ。
translation: On the shoji screen, I wrote, "Which one will bloom in the autumn?"

original: 妹の祇女も「姉身を投げば、我も共に身を投げんとこそ契りしか、まして世を厭はむに誰かは劣るべき。」とて十九にて樣をかへ、姉と一所に籠居て後世を願ふぞあはれなる。
translation: After that, I did not know where you were, but I changed my life and went to one place. I was very jealous of the time I had, but the Minister of the Buddha's Way did not have any more work.

original: 京中の白拍子ども祇王が幸の目出度きやうをきいてうらやむ者もあり、そねむ者もありけり。
translation: Some people in Kyoto envied Jōō for her good fortune, while others envied her.

original: 萠出るも枯るゝも同じ野邊の草、何れか秋にあはではつべき。
translation: Then she got on the carriage and went back to the inn, fell down on the shoji screen, and only cried.

original: さて車に乘て宿所に歸り、障子の内に倒れ臥し、唯泣くより外の事ぞき。
translation: Her mother and sister saw this and said, "How sad it is," but they could not even respond.

original: 母や妹是をみて「如何にやいかに。」ととひけれども、とかうの返事にも及ばず。
translation: They knew that the woman had told them this.

original: 具したる女に尋ねてぞさる事ありともしりてける。
translation: Thus, the monthly rice and silver that had been sent to her were now stopped, and those who had been close to Hō were now happy and prosperous.

original: さる程に毎月に送られつる百石百貫をも今はとゞめられて、佛御前がゆかりの者共ぞ、始めて、樂み榮えける。
translation: The people of Kyoto said, "Jōō has been summoned by the Minister of the Buddha's Way, so let us go and see her." Some sent letters, and others sent messengers.

original: 然るを中比より烏帽子、刀をのけられ、水干ばかりをもちゐたり、さてこそ白拍子とは名付けれ。
translation: But later, they removed the hat and the sword, and only kept the water-dry robe, and from then on, it was called the white dance.

original: 京中の上下、「祇王こそ入道殿よりいとま給はて出でたんなれ。いざ見參して遊ばむ。」とて、或は文をつかはす人もあり、或は使を立つる者もあり。
translation: But Jōō, having already been summoned, did not need to meet people again, so she did not accept any letters, and even did not know the messengers.

original: 後生でだに惡道へ趣かんずる事の悲しさよ。
translation: If I were in your place, I would not be happy.

original: 』と書置給ひし筆の跡、げにもと思ひさぶらひしぞや。
translation: It is the way of the world to change one's life because of sorrow.

original: その後は在所をいづくとも知りまゐらせざりつるに、かやうにさまを替て、一處にと承はて後は、あまりに羨しくて常は暇を申しかども、入道殿さらに御用ゐましまさず。
translation: Compared to the way of the world, this is not a great thing.

original: 今生でこそあらめ。
translation: I was sent back by Jōō's request, but I did not know how to control myself. I was sent back, but I thought of you and sang a song for you.

original: さき／＼召されたる處へはいれられずして、遙に下りたる處に座敷しつらうて置かれたり。
translation: After that, the Minister did not know what was in Jōō's heart, and said, "What has happened since then? Since Hō has been so eager to see you, sing a song now."

original: 其外白拍子二人、惣じて四人一車に乘て、西八條へぞ參たる。
translation: Hō saw this and felt very sorry, saying, "Even if you are not summoned, you should be allowed to come out and see her." But the Minister said, "There is no need for this ceremony," and Hō could not come out.

original: かげろふ稻妻よりも猶はかなし。
translation: It is a sad story.

original: 老少不定のさかひ、出づる息の入るをも待つべからず。
translation: Thus, the four of them, Jōō, Jōjo, Hō, and Tōji, were all entered into the past accounts of the Long Lecture Hall of the Emperor Kōken, as the four of them were together.

original: 年の若きを憑むべきにあらず。
translation: Let us all wish for it.

original: 此度泥梨に沈みては、多生昿劫をば隔つとも、浮み上らんこと難し。
translation: It is a good teacher to be happy.

original: 人身は受け難く、佛教には遇ひ難し。
translation: This year, a seventeen-year-old person, who hates the impure world and wishes for the pure world, deeply thinks of it, and this is truly the great way of the Buddha.

original: つく％＼物を案ずるに、娑婆の榮花は夢の夢、樂み榮えて何かせん。
translation: Hō has no sorrow or lamentation.

original: 佛御前是を見て、あまりにあはれに思ければ、「あれはいかに、日頃召されぬ所にても候はばこそ。是へ召され候へかし。さらずばわらはに暇を給べ。出でて見參せん。」と申ければ、入道「すべて其儀あるまじ。」と宣ふ間、力及ばで出でざりけり。
translation: Even the Buddha was once an ordinary person, and we will eventually become the Buddha. It is only sad that we are separated by this.

original: 祇王「こは、されば、何事ぞや。我身に過つ事は無けれども、すてられたてまつるだにあるに、座敷をさへ下げらるゝ事の心うさよ。いかにせむ。」と思ふに、知らせじと押ふる袖のひまよりも餘りて涙ぞこぼれける。
translation: Jōō thought that she should not disobey the Minister of the Buddha's Way, so she held back her tears and sang a song.

original: それに我御前は此三年まで思はれまゐらせたれば、ありがたき御情でこそあれ。
translation: Even if you are exiled from the capital, you and I are young, so it is easy to pass through the mountains.

original: 世に定なきものは男女の習なり。
translation: Only be exiled from the capital.

original: 白地とは思へどもながらへ果る事もあり。
translation: If you do not come, you will lose your life.

original: 千年萬年と契れども、軈て離るゝ中もあり。
translation: In addition, I have thought of you for three years, so it is a great kindness.

original: 男女の縁宿世今にはじめぬ事ぞかし。
translation: The world has no fixed things, but the habit of men and women.

original: [1]いかなるべしともおぼえす、なく／＼教訓しけるは、「いかに祇王御前、ともかくも御返事を申せかし、さやうにしかられ參らせんよりは。」といへば、祇王「參らんとおもふ道ならばこそやがて參るとも申さめ。參らざらんもの故に何と御返事を申すべしともおぼえず。此度めさんに參らずばはからふ旨ありと仰せらるゝは、都の外へ出さるゝか、さらずば命を召さるゝか、是二つによも過ぎじ。縱都を出さるゝとも、歎くべきにあらず。たとひ命を召さるゝとも、惜かるべき又わが身かは。一度憂きものに思はれ參らせて二度面をむかふべきにもあらず。」とて、なほ御返事をも申さゞりけるを、母とぢ重ねて教訓しけるは、「天が下に住ん程はともかうも入道殿の仰をば背くまじき事にてあるぞ。
translation: Even if you think it is white, it will eventually end.

original: 母とぢ是を聞くにかなしくて、
translation: Even if you have a thousand years of contracts, you will eventually part.

original: 入道も面白げにおもひ給ひて「時にとては神妙に申したり。
translation: "Thinking of disobeying my parents, I have seen two days of the world. If I am in this world, I will see more sorrow. Now I will throw my life away."

original: さてもあるべき事ならねば、祇王すでに、今はかうとて、出けるが、なからん跡の忘れ形見にもとや思ひけむ、障子になく／＼一首の歌をぞかきつけける。
translation: The grass in the field, whether it blooms or withers, will be the same in autumn.

original: 是につけても悲しくていとゞ涙にのみぞしづみける。
translation: Thus, the year ended without any change.

original: 佛御前はすげなういはれたてまつて車に乘て既にいでんとしけるが、めされて歸參りたり。
translation: The Minister said, "Go ahead, I will send you back. I will send someone to summon you."

original: そねむ者どもは「なん條名により、文字にはよるべき。幸はたゞ前世の生れつきにてこそあんなれ。」とてつかぬ者もおほかりけり。
translation: Those who envied her said, "What is the meaning of this name? It is only because of her birth in a previous life that she is so fortunate."

original: かくて三年と申に又都にきこえたる白拍子の上手一人出來たり。
translation: Thus, after three years, another master of the white dance was heard of in the capital.

original: 加賀國のものなり。
translation: He was from the province of Kaga.

original: 名をば佛とぞ申ける。
translation: His name was Hō.

original: 心も及ばず舞すましたりければ、入道相國舞にめで給ひて佛に心をうつされけり。
translation: Hō had a beautiful appearance from her hair to her figure, a good voice, and a good sense of rhythm, so her dance was also excellent.

original: 佛御前「こはされば何事さぶらふぞや。もとよりわらはは、推參の者にていだされまゐらせさぶらひしを、祇王御前の申状によてこそ召返されても候に、加樣にめしおかれなば、祇王御前の思ひ給はん心のうちはづかしうさぶらふ。はや／＼暇をたうで出させおはしませ。」と申ければ、入道、「すべて其儀あるまじ。但祇王があるをはゞかるか。其儀ならば祇王をこそいださめ。」と宣ひける。
translation: She finished her dance so beautifully that the Minister of the Buddha's Way was delighted and fell in love with her.

original: 佛御前「それ又いかでかさる御事候べき。諸共にめしおかれんだに心うう候べきに、まして祇王御前を出させ給ひて、わらは一人めしおかれなば、祇王御前の心のうちはづかしう候ふべし。おのづから後までわすれぬ御事ならば、めされて又は參るとも、今日は暇を給らむ。」とぞ申ける。
translation: Hō said, "What is this? I was summoned by the Minister of the Buddha's Way, but I was sent back by Jōō's request. If I am summoned again, Jōō will be very embarrassed. Please allow me to leave immediately."

original: 入道「なんでう其儀あるべき。
translation: The Minister said, "There is no need for this ceremony. But Jōō is there, so summon her."

original: 入道出あひ對面して「今日の見參はあるまじかりつるを、祇王が何と思ふやらん、餘りに申しすゝむる
translation: Hō was greatly honored and was about to leave on a carriage, but he was summoned back.

original: 間、か樣に見參しつ。
translation: The Minister came out and faced him, saying, "Today, there is no need for you to come, but I wonder what Jōō thinks of this."

original: 見參する程にてはいかで聲をもきかであるべきぞ。
translation: While he was there, he saw her come in this way.

original: 今樣一つうたへかし。
translation: How could you not hear her voice?

original: 」とのたまへば、佛御前「承りさぶらふ。」とて今樣一つぞ歌うたる。
translation: Please sing one song now.

original: 君をはじめて見るをりは、千代も歴ぬべし姫小松、御前の池なる龜岡に、鶴こそ群れ居て遊ぶめれ。
translation: "Hō said, "I will sing."

original: 佛御前はすげなういはれたてまつて、已にいでんとしけるを、祇王、入道殿に申けるは「あそび者の推參は常の習でこそ候へ。其上、年もいまだをさなう候ふなるが、たま／＼思たてまゐりて候を、すげなう仰られてかへさせ給はん事こそ不便なれ。いかばかりはづかしうかたはらいたくも候ふらむ。わがたてし道なれば、人の上ともおぼえず。たとひ舞を御覽じ、歌をきこしめさずとも、御對面ばかりさぶらうてかへさせ給ひたらば、ありがたき御情でこそ候はんずれ。たゞ理をまげて、めしかへして御對面さぶらへ。」と申ければ、入道、「いで／＼、我御前があまりにいふ事なれば、見參してかへさむ。」とてつかひを立てぞめされける。
translation: Hō was greatly honored, and he was about to leave, but Jōō said to the Minister of the Buddha's Way, "It is customary for those who wish to see a game to come. In addition, I am still young, but I have come to see you, and I have been greatly honored. It is inconvenient for me to be sent back. I am very embarrassed. I do not consider myself above others. Even if you do not see my dance or hear my song, I would be very grateful if I could only see you. Please allow me to see you."

original: 人まゐて「當時都にきこえ候佛御前こそまゐて候へ。」と申しければ、入道「なんでうさやうのあそびものは人の召に隨てこそ參れ。左右なう推參する樣やある。祇王があらん處へは神ともいへ、佛ともいへ、かなふまじきぞ。とう／＼罷出よ。」とぞの給ひける。
translation: When people came and said, "The master of the white dance who was heard of in the capital has come," the Minister said, "Why should a game of this kind be summoned by people? It is only proper for the left and right to summon her. Where Jōō is, it is as if it were a god or a Buddha, so it is not proper to go against her will. Go ahead and come."

original: さやうの事あるべしとも知らずして教訓して參らせつる事の心うさよ。
translation: When they saw the sunset on the western mountain, they thought of the Western Pure Land.

original: 但我御前身を
translation: One day, they will be born there and think of things. Even so, they continued to think of the things they had suffered before, and only tears remained.

original: [2]投げは、妹もともに身を投げんといふ。
translation: When the evening came, they closed the bamboo screen and lit a small lamp, and the three of them, mother and daughter,念佛. Then, someone came and hit the bamboo screen.

original: 二人の娘共に後れなん後、年老衰へたる母命いきてもなにゝかはせむなれば、我もともに身を投げむとおもふなり。
translation: The nuns were frightened and said, "Alas, this is the evil karma that is preventing us from念佛. It is the coming of the evil karmic bond. It is a quiet mountain village with a thatched hut, and at night, someone will come to look for you. It is easy to break the bamboo screen. I think it is just to open it. If you do not have feelings, you will lose your life. You should strongly believe in the vow of Amida Buddha and constantly recite the name. If the holy beings come to welcome you, you should not refuse them. Do not be lazy in念佛."

original: 年十六とぞきこえし。
translation: He was sixteen years old.

original: 「昔よりおほくの白拍子ありしかども、かかる舞は、いまだ見ず。」とて京中の上下もてなす事なのめならず。
translation: "Although there have been many masters of the white dance in the past, I have never seen a dance like this," said the people of Kyoto, and they treated her with great honor.

original: 障子にまた、『いづれか秋にあはではつべき。
translation: It is as if we were not for the world. People said it, and I thought it too.

original: 佛御前があまりにつれ／＼げに見ゆるに、まゐて今樣をもうたひ、舞などをも舞て佛なぐさめよ。
translation: Her mother heard this and was very sad.

original: かある。
translation: "The Minister said, "Jōō did not even reply. Should I not come? If I should not come, then say so. The Minister Netai has already decided."

original: 」とぞ宣ひける。
translation: "No matter what, I will teach her, "I think you should at least reply, but if you don't, then you will be summoned. If you are summoned, you will be exiled from the capital or your life will be taken. These are the two options. Even if you are exiled from the capital, it is not worth grieving. Even if your life is taken, it is not worth grieving. Once you are in trouble, you will not be able to see her again."

original: 佛御前は髮姿よりはじめてみめ形うつくしく聲よく節も上手でありければ、なじかは舞もそんずべき。
translation: She performed the first dance.

original: うたせて一番舞たりけり。
translation: The Minister thought it was interesting and said, "You are very skilled in this song. I think you should also perform the dance. Please perform the first dance. Beat the drum."

original: 入道もおもしろげに思ひ給ひて、「我御前は今樣は上手でありけるよ。此定では舞も定めてよかるらん。一番見ばや。鼓打めせ。」とてめされけり。
translation: When she finished singing it three times, the people who heard it were all astonished.

original: とおし返し／＼三返歌すましたりければ、見聞の人々みな耳目をおどろかす。
translation: When I first saw you, the thousand-year pine tree, the young princess of Koyasu, the turtle hill in the pond of the Minister, the cranes gathered and played.

original: 祇王とかうの御返事にも及ばず。
translation: Jōō did not even reply, and her mother kept teaching her, saying, "It is not proper to disobey the Minister of the Buddha's Way, who lives in the heavens.

original: 此世は假の宿なり。
translation: Jōō said, "What is this? Is this Hō? Is it a dream or a hallucination?"

original: いまだ死期も來らぬ親に身を投げさせん事五逆罪にやあらんずらむ。
translation: When they opened the bamboo screen, it was not the evil karmic bond, but Hō.

original: 慚ても慚ても何ならず。
translation: Hō held back her tears and said, "If I had said this, it would have been strange, but if I did not say it, I would have been forgotten. So I will say it from the beginning.

original: 佛御前申けるは「我天下に聞えたれども、當時さしもめでたうさかえさせ給ふ平家太政の入道殿へめされぬ事こそ本意なけれ。あそびもののならひ、なにかはくるしかるべき。推參して見む。」とて、ある時西八條へぞまゐりたる。
translation: Hō said, "I have heard of you all over the world, but I have never been summoned by the great Minister of the Buddha's Way, who is the most honored. It is only a game, so I will go and see for myself." So he went to the West Eight Streets at a certain time.

original: いつか我身の上ならんと思へば、嬉しとは更におもはず。
translation: This time, I will achieve my wish of rebirth, which is more joyful than anything else.

original: 唯都の外へぞ出されんずらん。
translation: It is sad to live in a place you have never stayed before.

original: めさんに參らねばとて命をうしなはるゝまではよもあらじ。
translation: Only if you are old and feeble, you will be exiled from the capital.

original: 泣々又教訓しけるは「誠に我御前の恨むるもことわりなり。
translation: Thus, the spring passed, and the summer was over. When the autumn wind blew, they looked at the stars in the sky and thought of the leaves on the katsura tree.

original: 母とぢ、是をきくに悲しくていかなるべしともおぼえず。
translation: Her mother saw this and, seeing her young daughters change their lives, at forty-five, she also shaved her hair and lived with her daughters,念佛 and hoping for the next life.

original: 「親の命を背かじとつらき道におもむいて、二度、うき目を見つる事の心うさよ。かくて此世にあるならば、又憂き目をも見むずらん。今は只身を投げんとおもふなり。」といへば妹の祇女も「姉身を投げば、われもともに身を投ん。」といふ。
translation: Her sister, Jōjo, also said, "If you throw your life away, I will throw mine as well." At nineteen, she changed her life and lived with her sister, hoping for the next life.

original: 祇王とかくの返事にも及ばず、涙を押へて出でにけり。
translation: At twenty-one, Jōō became a nun and lived in a mountain village in Sagano,念佛 and living in a thatched hut.

original: 」とぞ宣ひける。
translation: Jōō held back her tears and said, "If I do this, it is a great sin. I will not do it. If I am in the capital, I will see more sorrow. Now I will go out of the capital."

original: 祇王「あれはいかに。佛御前と見奉るは夢かや、うつゝか。」といひければ、佛御前涙をおさへて、「か樣の事申せば、事あたらしう候へども、申さずば、又思ひ知らぬ身ともなりぬべければ、始よりして申すなり。
translation: When she saw the clothes she had carried, she was a nun.

original: その時尼ども膽をけし「あはれ、是はいひかひなき我等が念佛してゐたるを妨げんとて、魔縁のきたるにてぞあるらん。晝だにも人の問ひ來ぬ山里の柴の庵の内なれば、夜深て誰かは尋ぬべき。僅の竹の編戸なれば、あけずとも推破んこと安かるべし。なか／＼たゞあけていれんと思ふなり。それに情をかけずして、命を失ふものならば、年比頼たてまつる彌陀の本願を強く信じて、ひまなく名號を唱へ奉るべし。聲を尋ねて迎へ給ふなる聖衆の來迎にてましませば、などか引接なかるべき。相構へて念佛怠り給ふな。」と、互に心をいましめて、竹の編戸をあけたれば、魔縁にてはなかりけり、佛御前ぞ出できたる。
translation: Proud of the joy of this moment, not knowing the sorrow of the next life, I came out this morning and came to see you.

original: 黄昏時も過ぎぬれば竹の編戸を閉じ塞ぎ、燈かすかにかきたてて、親子三人念佛して居たる處に、竹の編戸を、ほと／＼と打ちたゝく者出できたり。
translation: It is more pitiful than the lightning.

original: いつか我等も彼處に生れて物を思はですぐさんずらんと、かゝるにつけても過ぎにし方の憂き事ども思ひ續けて、たゞ盡せぬ物は涙なり。
translation: It is not right to wait for the breath of the old.

original: 佛も昔は凡夫なり、我等も遂には佛なり、何も佛性具せる身を、隔つるのみこそ悲しけれ。
translation: The Minister thought it was interesting and said, "It was sincere. You have seen the dance, but today you have been busy. From now on, you should sing the song and dance to comfort her."

original: と泣く／＼二返歌うたりければ、其座にいくらも並居たまへる平家一門の公卿、殿上人、諸大夫、侍に至るまで皆感涙をぞ流されける。
translation: Jōō did not even reply and left in tears.

original: 祇王御前の申状によてこそ、召し返されても候ふに、女のかひなきこと、我身を心に任せずして、おしとゞめられまゐらせし事心うゝさぶらひしが、いつぞや又めされまゐらせていまやううたひ給ひしにも思しられてこそさぶらへ。
translation: Jōō held back her tears and said, "I truly thought this way. I did not even know it was a dream. In the sorrowful world, I should think of my body's sorrow, but I thought only of the sorrow of the world. I did not know how to achieve my wish of rebirth, but I thought it was my fault for being too careless in this life and the next. If I changed my life like this, the fault of the day would be as small as a drop of dew. Now, I have no doubt about rebirth."

original: もとよりわらは推參の者にて、出され參らせ候ひしを、
translation: "Since I have changed my life like this, I will be forgiven. If I am forgiven, I will all念佛 and become one lotus flower. If I still do not have the right heart, I will be lost in the world, and I will fall on the moss and pine roots and念佛 until my life ends, and I will achieve my wish of rebirth."

original: て今樣をも歌ひ、舞などを舞て佛なぐさめよ。
translation: She cried and said, "It is truly my fault. I did not know that this would happen. It is very sad that I taught her this. But if you throw your life away, your sister will also throw hers. If both of you are gone, I will also throw mine. It is a great sin to throw your life away before your parents are dead. This world is only a temporary stay. I am ashamed, but I have no choice. It is only the long darkness of this world that is sad. I will do it in this life. In the next life, I will go to a bad place. It is very sad."

original: 此後は召さずとも、常に參
translation: Her mother heard this and was very sad, not knowing what to say.

original: さては舞も見たけれども、今日は紛るゝ事いできたり。
translation: Her sister, Jōjo, also said, "If you throw your life away, I will throw mine as well."

original: 唯長き世の闇こそ心うけれ。
translation: Originally, I was summoned by the Minister of the Buddha's Way, but I was sent back by Jōō's request.

original: 世にはいかにして漏れけるやらん、哀にやさしきためしにぞ人々申しあへりける。
translation: The Great Imperial Consort, after a brief period of learning, did not even complete her studies, and her name was known as Kawa竹, which was not well known in the world.

original: 只深淵にのぞんで薄氷をふむに同じ、主上上皇、父子の御間には何事の御隔かあるべきなれども、思の外の事どもありけり。
translation: It is like looking into a deep abyss and stepping on thin ice; although the Emperor and his father should have no separation, there were things beyond expectation.

original: 就中に永暦應保の比よりして、院の近習者をば、内より御誡あり、内の近習者をば、院より誡めらるゝ間、上下おそれをのゝいて、安い心もなし。
translation: Among these, compared to the years of Eiraku and Eikō, the Emperor's close attendants were reprimanded from within, and those within the court who were close attendants were reprimanded by the Emperor, and thus the upper and lower ranks were in fear, with no sense of ease.

original: 大宮敢て聞食しもいれず。
translation: The Great Imperial Consort did not dare to accept the letter.

original: 主上院の仰を常に申かへさせおはしましける中にも、人耳目を驚し、世以て大きに傾け申すことありけり。
translation: Even while the Emperor constantly deferred to the court's will, there were events that shocked the people and caused the world to greatly tilt.

original: 故近衞院の后、太皇太后宮と申しは大炊御門右大臣公能公の御娘なり。
translation: The former consort of the late Emperor, known as the Great Imperial Consort, was the daughter of the Minister of the Right, Kōno no Kiyomori.

original: さる程に、永萬元年の春の比より、主上御不豫の御事と聞えさせ給ひしが、夏の初になりしかば、事の外に重らせ給ふ。
translation: That time, the sorrowful events that were spoken of were indeed pitiful.

original: 是も世澆季に及んで、人梟惡を先とする故なり。
translation: This is also due to the fact that in this age of decadence, people prioritize evil over good.

original: されども鳥羽院、御晏駕の後は、兵革打ち續き、死罪、流刑、闕官、停任、常に行はれて、海内も靜かならず。
translation: However, after the Emperor's retreat from the imperial court, warfare continued, and punishments such as death, exile, removal from office, and suspension of duties were constantly carried out, and the land was not at peace.

original: 如何ならん末の代までも、何事かあらむとぞ見えし。
translation: How could it be seen that something would happen even in the distant future?

original: その時の有職の人々申しあはれけるは、本朝に、童帝の例を尋ぬれば、清和天皇九歳にして、文徳天皇の御禪を受けさせ給ふ。
translation: Thus, it was heard that the daughter of Dazō no Dajō, Igi Kanehira, who was pregnant with the first son of the current Emperor, should be made the crown prince, and on the twenty-fifth day of the sixth month, suddenly an imperial decree was issued, and that night, the Emperor accepted the throne, causing great confusion throughout the world.

original: 昔より今に至るまで、源平兩氏朝家に召しつかはれて、王化に隨はず、自朝權を輕んずる者には、互に誡を加しかば、代の亂れもなかりしに、保元に爲義きられ、平治に義朝誅せられて後は、末々の源氏ども、或は流され、或は失はれ、今は平家の一類のみ繁昌して、頭をさし出す者なし。
translation: From ancient times until now, the Minamoto and Taira clans have been summoned to serve the imperial court, but those who did not follow the imperial way and instead seized power for themselves were mutually warned, and thus there was no disorder for generations. However, after the Emperor was deposed in the Hōgen Rebellion and Minamoto no Yoshitomo was executed in the Heiji Rebellion, the descendants of the Minamoto clan were either exiled or lost their status, and now only the Taira clan has flourished, with no one to rival them.

original: 大宮ものうき御出立なれば、とみにもたてまつらず。
translation: Since the day of her entry into the palace had already arrived, the father, the Minister of the Right, arranged the ceremony of the imperial procession and the departure, and she participated in them with great care.

original: 遙に夜も深け、小夜も半になて後、御車に抜け乘せられ給ひけり。
translation: The Great Imperial Consort's departure was so quiet that no one stood in attendance.

original: 」とて、やがて御入内の日、宣下せられける上は、力及ばせ給はず。
translation: And so, on the day of her entry into the palace, he did not exert his power to prevent it.

original: されども、天下第一の美人の聞えまし／＼ければ、主上色にのみ染める御心にて、竊に高力士に詔して、外宮に引き求めしむるに及んで、この大宮へ御艶書あり。
translation: However, since she was known as the most beautiful woman in the world, the Emperor was so captivated by her that he secretly ordered the high-ranking official Kō no Moroyasu to bring her to the imperial palace, and thus, the Great Imperial Consort received a love letter from the Emperor.

original: 世間も末落居せず。
translation: The world also did not remain stable.

original: 上皇も然るべからざるよし、こしらへ申させ給へば、主上仰なりけるは、「天子に父母なし、我十善の戒功によて、萬乘の寶
translation: The Emperor also considered this to be inappropriate, and upon being advised, he said, "The Son of Heaven has no parents; I have relied on the ten virtues to protect my position as the ruler of ten thousand chariots."

original: 大宮その比、なにとなき御手習の次に、うきふしにしづみもやらで河竹の、世にためしなき名をやながさん。
translation: However, she did not give any reply.

original: その間の御なからへ、いひしらず哀にやさしかりし御事なり。
translation: Though sorrowful, she had come to meet him, and now they would see the same moon at the Cloud Well.

original: 父の大臣、こしらへ申させ給ひけるは、「世に從はざるを以て、狂人とすと見えたり。既に詔命を下さる。仔細を申すにところなし。只速に參らせ給ふべきなり。もし皇子御誕生ありて、君も國母といはれ、愚老も外祖と仰がるべき瑞相にてもや候ふらむ。是偏に愚老をたすけさせおはします御孝行の御至なるべし。」と、申させ給へども、御返事もなかりけり。
translation: The father, the Minister of the Right, advised her, saying, "Because you are not following the world, you seem to be a madman. The imperial decree has already been issued, and there is no room for further explanation. You must come quickly. If the Emperor gives birth to a son, he will be called the Son of Heaven and the mother will be called the Empress, and even the old man will be called the grandfather. This is a most virtuous act of filial piety, helping the old man."

original: 先帝に後させ參らせにし久壽の秋のはじめ、同じ野原の露と消え、家をも出、世をも遁れたりせば、かゝる憂き耳をば聞かざらましとぞ、御歎ありける。
translation: At the beginning of the autumn when she was left behind by the late Emperor, she vanished like the dew on the same field, leaving behind her family and fleeing from the world. Thus, she lamented that she would not hear such sorrowful words.

original: 大宮かくと聞しめされけるより、御涙に沈ませおはします。
translation: Upon hearing this, the Great Imperial Consort was deeply moved to tears.

original: 位をたもつ、是程のこと、などか叡慮に任せざるべき。
translation: "This is a matter of such great importance that it should be entrusted to my wisdom."

original: 是によて、大藏の大輔伊吉兼盛が娘の腹に、今上の一の宮の二歳にならせ給ふがまし／＼けるを、太子にたてまゐらせ給ふべしと聞えし程に、同六月二十五日、俄に親王の宣旨下されて、やがてその夜受禪ありしかば、天下何となうあわてたるさま也。
translation: In this way, in the spring of the first year of Eimyō, it was heard that the Emperor was unwell, and by the beginning of summer, the matter became even more severe.

original: 「先づ異朝の先蹤をとぶらふに、震旦の則天皇后は、唐の太宗の后、高宗皇帝の繼母なり。太宗崩御の後、高宗の后に立ち給へることあり。それは異朝の先規たる上、別段の事なり。然れども我朝には、神武天皇より以降、人皇七十餘代に及まで、いまだ二代の后に立たせ給へる例を聞かず。」と、諸卿一同に申されけり。
translation: "If we look at the precedent in other dynasties, the Empress Wu of the Tang Dynasty was the wife of Emperor Taizong and the stepmother of Emperor Gaozong. After Emperor Taizong's death, she became the empress of Emperor Gaozong. This is an established precedent in other dynasties, and thus it is a special case. However, in our dynasty, since the reign of Emperor Jinmu, there has never been a case of a second empress being established for seventy or more generations."

original: 此事天下に於て、異なる勝事なれば、公卿僉議あり、各意見をいふ。
translation: This matter, being an unusual event in the world, caused a debate among the court officials, and each gave their opinion.

original: されば、ひたすらはやほに現はれて、后御入内あるべきよし、右大臣家に宣旨を下さる。
translation: Therefore, she appeared hastily, and it was decided that she would enter the palace, and an imperial decree was issued to the Minister of the Right's household.

original: 先帝に後れ奉らせ給ひて後は、九重の外、近衞川原の御所にぞ移り住ませ給ひける。
translation: After she was left behind by the late Emperor, she moved to the residence at the banks of the Kōno River, outside the nine-tiered palace.

original: 前の后の宮にて、幽なる御在樣にて渡らせ給ひしが、永歴のころほひは、御年二十二三にもやならせたまひけん、御盛りも少し過させおはしますほどなり。
translation: She had lived in seclusion at the former imperial palace, but by the time of Eiraku, she was around twenty-two or twenty-three years old, and had already passed her prime.

original: 既に御入内の日になりしかば、父の大臣供奉の上達部、出車の儀式など、心ことにだしたて參らせ給ひけり。
translation: How could the world not know of such a sorrowful story? People spoke of it with compassion.

original: 思ひきや憂き身ながらにめぐり來て、おなじ雲井の月を見むとは。
translation: The former Emperor, who was still young, had previously written something, and after she had secretly written it, when she saw that it had not changed at all, she recalled that the late Emperor must have loved her deeply.

original: 尾張守小野道風が、七囘賢聖の障子と書
translation: Rokuri Shōshin, Li Ji, Sima, Shouchō, Shuchō, and the horse-shaped screen, the ghost room, and a screen depicting the figure of General Li, as if he were painted.

original: けるも、理とぞ見えし。
translation: Oshō no Morofuji wrote the seven return screens of the wise and virtuous men,

original: 故院の未幼主にてましましけるそのかみ、何となき御手まさぐりの次に、かきくもらかさせ給ひしが、ありしながらに少しもたがはぬを御覽じて、先帝の昔もや御戀しくおぼし召されけん。
translation: On the screen of the painting in the清凉殿, there was the image of the distant mountain and the moon at the end of the mountain, which was said to have been painted by Kinō.

original: かの清凉殿の畫圖の御障子には、昔金岡が書きたりし遠山の在明の月もありとかや。
translation: and it was said to be in accordance with reason.

original: 彼紫宸殿の皇居には、賢聖の障子を立てられたり。
translation: She was solely devoted to assisting in the governance of the court.

original: 伊尹、第伍倫、虞世南、太公望、
translation: In the Purple宸殿 imperial palace, screens with the images of wise and virtuous men were set up.

original: ろく里先生、李勣、司馬、手長、足長、馬形の障子、鬼の間、李將軍が姿をさながら寫せる障子もあり。
translation: There were screens depicting Yi Yin, the Fifth Lord, Yu Shi Nan, Taigong Wang,

original: 物さわがしともおろかなり。
translation: There was no precedent for this.

original: 先例なし。
translation: They said that he would become the Emperor, and now he was two years old.

original: かれをこそいつしかなりと申しに、是は二歳にならせ給ふ。
translation: The Emperor was five years old, and the Emperor of the Kōno Court was three years old when they ascended the throne.

original: 鳥羽院五歳、近衞院三歳にて踐祚あり。
translation: This was the beginning of the regency.

original: それは彼周公旦の成王に代り、南面にして、一日萬機の政を治め給ひしに准へて、外祖忠仁公、幼主を扶持し給へり。
translation: At that time, the officials of the court said, "If we look for precedents in our dynasty, there is the case of Emperor Seiwa, who was nine years old when he received the throne from Emperor Junnin.

original: 是ぞ攝政のはじめなる。
translation: This was comparable to the case of Duke Zhou, who ruled in the place of King Cheng, governing the affairs of the state for one day, and the loyal and kind Prince Zhongren, who supported the young Emperor.

original: ひたすら、朝政をすゝめ申させ給ふ御在樣なり。
translation: After her entry into the palace, she resided in the Reikyōden.

original: 御入内の後は、麗景殿にぞまし／＼ける。
translation: After a long night, when the small night had passed halfway, she quietly climbed into the carriage.

original: 先づ聖武天皇の御願、爭ふべき寺なければ、東大寺の額をうつ。
translation: First, if there was no temple to dispute over, the banner of Tōdai-ji would be hung for Emperor Shōmu's wish.

original: 然るを山門の大衆、いかがおもひけん、先例を背て、東大寺の次ぎ、興福寺のうへに、延暦寺の額を打つ間、南都の大衆、とやせましかやうせましと僉議するところに、興福寺の西金堂の衆、觀音房、勢至房とて聞えたる大惡僧二人ありけり。
translation: However, the monks of the gate were deliberating whether to follow the precedent or not, deciding to place Enryaku-ji's banner after Tōdai-ji and Kōfuku-ji. At this time, two notorious monks from the West Golden Hall of Kōfuku-ji, known as Kannon-ma and Shishi-ma, were present.

original: 次に天武天皇の御願、教待和尚、智證大師の草創とて、園城寺の額をうつ。
translation: Next, for Emperor Tenmu's wish and the founding by Kōtai-ji and Jishō Daishi, the banner of Enryaku-ji would be hung.

original: 北京には、興福寺に向へて延暦寺の額をうつ。
translation: In the northern capital, facing Kōfuku-ji, the banner of Enryaku-ji would be hung.

original: 次に淡海公の御願とて、興福寺の額をうつ。
translation: Next, for the wish of Prince Takama, the banner of Kōfuku-ji would be hung.

original: 觀音房は黒絲威の腹卷に、白柄の長刀くきみじかに取り、勢至房は、萠黄威の腹卷に、黒漆の大太刀もて、二人つと走出で、延暦寺の額をきて落し、散々に打わり、「うれしや水、なるは瀧の水、日はてるとも、絶えずとうたへ。」とはやしつゝ、南都の衆徒の中へぞ入りにける。
translation: Kannon-ma wore a black silk belt and a white-patterned long sword, while Shishi-ma wore a yellow belt and a black lacquered great sword. Both rushed out, pulled down the banner of Enryaku-ji, and fiercely attacked, singing, "Happy is the water, which is the water of the waterfall; though the day ends, it never ceases." As they sang, they entered among the monks of the southern capital.

original: 一天の君崩御なて後、御墓所へわたし奉る時の作法は、南北二京の大衆悉く供奉して、御墓所の廻に、わが寺々の額をうつことあり。
translation: After the emperor's death, the customary practice for the funeral procession to the tomb site involved the monks of the northern and southern capitals all participating, with each temple's banners being hung around the tomb.

original: やがて、その夜、香隆寺の艮、蓮臺野の奧、船岡山にをさめ奉る。
translation: Later that night, they moved to the north-east of Karamon-ji, deep in Rendai no Hara, and to Funago-yama.

original: 御葬送の時、延暦寺、興福寺の大衆、額打論といふ事しいだして、互に狼藉に及ぶ。
translation: During the funeral, the monks of Enryaku-ji and Kōfuku-ji raised a dispute over the order of hanging banners, leading to chaos.

original: 御歳二十三。
translation: His age was twenty-three.

original: さる程に、同七月廿七日、上皇竟に崩御なりぬ。
translation: Thus, on the same July 27th, the retired emperor died.

original: 玉の簾、錦の帳のうち、皆御涙に咽ばせ給ふ。
translation: Within the jade curtain and brocade canopy, all were choked with imperial tears.

original: 蕾める花の散れるが如し。
translation: Like a flower that had just begun to bloom, scattering away.

original: 檢非違使、西坂本に馳向て、防ぎけれども、事ともせずおしやぶて亂入す。
translation: The inspection officials, rushing to the western slope of Sakamoto, tried to prevent them, but the matter could not be stopped, and they stormed in.

original: 中々惡しき御事なり。
translation: Lord Shigemasa replied, "Even though this matter is clearly wrong, it should not be allowed to be mentioned, for if people are given a chance to act recklessly...

original: それにつけても叡慮に背き給はで、人のために御なさけを施させましまさば、神明三寶加護あるべし。
translation: This is truly a most unfortunate matter.

original: 一院も、急ぎ六波羅へ御幸なる。
translation: The One Emperor also hurried to Rokuhara.

original: 清盛公其比、いまだ大納言にておはしけるが、大に恐れさわがれけり。
translation: At that time, Lord Kiyomori was still a minister, but he was greatly alarmed.

original: 小松殿「何によてか、唯今さる事あるべき。」と、しづめられけれども、上下ののしりさわぐことおびたゞし。
translation: Lord Komatsu said, "By what means could such a thing happen now?" but despite this, the upper and lower ranks were greatly agitated.

original: 山門の大衆、六波羅へは寄せずして、すずろなる清水寺におしよせて、佛閣僧房一宇も殘さず燒はらふ。
translation: The crowd at the mountain gate did not go to Rokuhara, but instead approached the quiet temple of Kiyomizu, and burned down every single hall and monk's room without leaving one intact.

original: 是はさんぬる御葬送の夜の會稽の耻を雪めんがためとぞ聞えし。
translation: It was said that this was to avenge the disgrace of the night of the burial at Yue, which had been a great humiliation.

original: 一詞も出さず。
translation: Not uttering a single word.

original: 御門かくれさせ給ひては、心なき草木までも、愁へたる色にてこそあるべきに、この
translation: Having concealed the gate, even heartless grass and trees would surely take on a sorrowful hue, but this...

original: 騒動のあさましさに、高きも賤きも、肝魂を失て四方へ皆退散す。
translation: Because of the turbulence and disorder, both the high and the low lost their courage and scattered in all directions.

original: 同二十九日の午の刻ばかり、山門の大衆おびたゞしう下洛すと聞えしかば、武士、
translation: On the twenty-ninth day of the month, at the hour of the horse, it was heard that the crowd at the mountain gate had descended to the capital in great numbers, so the warriors...

original: 重盛卿、御送よりかへられたりければ、父の大納言の給ひけるは、「一院の御幸こそ大きに恐れおぼゆれ。かねても思しめしより、仰せらるゝ旨のあればこそかうは聞ゆらめ、それにも打解給ふまじ。」とのたまへば、重盛卿申されけるは、「此事ゆめ／＼御けしきにも、御詞にも出させ給ふべからず、人に心附けがほに、
translation: When Lord Shigemasa returned from the procession, his father, the minister, said, "The Emperor's visit is greatly alarming. Even though I have always been concerned, I heard this because of the Emperor's words, and I should not have allowed it."

original: 衆徒返り上りければ、一院六波羅より還御なる。
translation: When the people returned, the One Emperor returned from Rokuhara.

original: 重盛卿ばかりぞ、御ともには參られける。
translation: Only Lord Shigemasa attended.

original: 猶用心のためかとぞ聞えし。
translation: It was said that this was for caution.

original: 父の卿は參られず。
translation: His father did not attend.

original: 境節御前近う候ひけるが、「天に口なし、人を以ていはせよと申す。平家以外に過分に候間、天の御計らひにや。」とぞ申しける。
translation: After the One Emperor returned, many attendants who were close to him gathered before him, and said, "It is indeed strange that someone has spoken such a thing. It is as if they have not even noticed the dew."

original: 一院還御の後、御前にうとからぬ近習者達あまた候はれけるに、「さても不思議の事を申し出したるものかな。露もおぼし召よらぬものを。」と仰ければ、院中の切者に西光法師といふ者あり。
translation: " said this, and then stood up. His father said, "Lord Shigemasa is indeed a noble and dignified person."

original: 清水寺は、興福寺の末寺たるによてなり。
translation: Kiyomizu Temple was a sub-temple of Kōfuku-ji.

original: 平氏の一類、皆六波羅へ馳集る。
translation: All the followers of the Heike gathered at Rokuhara.

original: 清水寺燒けたりける朝、何者の態にや在けん、「觀音火坑變成池はいかに」と札に書て、大門の前にたてたりければ、次の日、又「歴劫不思議力不及」と、返しの札をぞ打たりける。
translation: On the morning when Kiyomizu Temple was burned, someone wrote on a piece of paper, "The fire pit of Kannon becomes a pond, how is this?" and placed it before the main gate. The next day, another paper was placed, reading, "The power of countless eons is inconceivable and beyond reach."

original: 人々「この事よしなし。壁に耳あり、おそろしおそろし。」とぞ申あはれける。
translation: There was a monk named Saishō in the court who said, "The heavens have no mouth; therefore, let people speak. If there is any excess beyond the Heike, it is the will of heaven."

original: 」とて、立たれければ「重盛卿は、ゆゝしく大樣なるものかな。」とぞ父の卿ものたまひける。
translation: Therefore, you need not fear for your own safety.

original: さらんにとては、御身の恐れ候ふまじ。
translation: Even so, if you do not go against your wisdom and show mercy for the sake of others, the gods and the Three Jewels will surely protect you.

translation: Whoever had made this request, the One Emperor commanded the crowd at the mountain gate to pursue the Heike, and it was heard that the soldiers entered the palace and guarded the four sides of the battlefield.

original: 山門の大衆、狼藉をいたさば、手向へすべき處に、心深うねらふ方もやありけん。
translation: The crowd at the mountain gate, having caused disorder, there might be those who, in their hearts, plotted deeply.

original: 三條院十一歳にて東宮に立せ給ふ。
translation: The Lady Kōshunmon-in was appointed as Crown Prince at the age of eleven.

original: 又平大納言時忠卿と申も、女院の御兄なれば、内の御外戚なり。
translation: Moreover, the Minister of the Left, Heike no Tadamasa, was the brother of the Lady of the Imperial Court, and thus a member of the imperial in-laws.

original: 仁安三年三月二十日、新帝大極殿にして御即位あり。
translation: On the twentieth day of the third month of the third year of the Jinnan era, the new emperor ascended the throne in the Daitoku Hall.

original: 但し寛和二年、一條院七歳にて御即位。
translation: However, in the second year of the Kōan era, the Lady Kōshunmon-in ascended the throne at the age of seven.

original: 春宮は御伯父六歳、主上は御甥三歳、何れも昭穆に相叶はず。
translation: The Crown Prince was six years old, the Emperor was three years old, and neither was in accordance with the proper order of succession.

original: 叙位除目と申すも、偏にこの時忠卿のまゝなり。
translation: The granting of ranks and appointments was entirely in the hands of this Tadamasa.

original: 入道相國天下の大小事をのたまひあはせられければ、時の人平關白とぞ申しける。
translation: Because the monk-Prime Minister governed all the great and small affairs of the country, the people of that time called him the Heike Chancellor.

original: 内外につけたる執權の臣とぞ見えし。
translation: Thus, it seemed that the power of the Heike clan was firmly established both within and outside the court.

original: 世のおぼえ、時のきら、めでたかりき。
translation: The world was filled with admiration and the time was glorious.

original: 楊貴妃が幸ひし時、楊國忠が盛えし如し。
translation: It was just as when Yang Guifei was favored, and Yang Guozhong flourished.

original: 位をすべらせ給て、新院とぞ申ける。
translation: He was granted the title and called the New Imperial Palace.

original: 御母儀建春門院と申すは、平家の一門にてましますうへ、とりわき入道相國の北の方、二位殿の御妹なり。
translation: The Lady Kōshunmon-in, the mother of the Emperor, lived in the Heike family, and was the daughter of the former Prime Minister, the monk who had been the wife of the Northern Court, and the younger sister of the Lady of the Second Rank.

original: 此君の位につかせ給ぬるは、いよ／＼平家の榮花とぞ見えし。
translation: It was clearly evident that the appointment of this emperor was the height of the prosperity of the Heike clan.

original: 同年の十月八日、去年親王の宣旨蒙らせ給し皇子、東三條にて春宮に立たせ給ふ。
translation: On the eighth day of the tenth month of the same year, the prince who had received the imperial decree from the Prince the previous year was appointed as the Crown Prince at Tōsanjō.

original: 明くれば、改元ありて仁安と號す。
translation: When it became clear, the era was changed and named Jinnan.

original: 同十二月二十四日、建春門院その比はいまだ東の御方と申しける御腹に、一院の宮まし／＼けるが、親王の宣旨下され給ふ。
translation: On the twenty-fourth day of the twelfth month, the Lady Kōshunmon-in, who was still said to be in the eastern quarters, had the Emperor's younger brother, the Crown Prince, brought to her, and the Prince received an imperial decree.

original: さる程に、その年は諒闇なりければ、御禊大甞會も行はれず。
translation: So it was that in that year, because of the confusion, the imperial purification and great ceremonial feast were not held.

original: いまだ御元服もなくして、太上天皇の尊號あり。
translation: He had not yet performed the coming-of-age ceremony, yet the title of the Emperor was already given to him.

original: 漢家本朝是やはじめならむ。
translation: This was the beginning of the Han Chinese tradition of the imperial court.

original: 先例なきにしもあらず。
translation: This was not without precedent.

original: 主上は二歳にて御禪を受けさせ給ひ、纔に五歳と申二月十九日、東宮踐祚ありしかば、
translation: The Emperor was made to abdicate at the age of two, and only on the nineteenth day of the second month, when he was five years old, did he ascend the throne as Crown Prince.

original: 前驅御隨身共が今日を晴としやうぞいたるを、あそこに追かけ、こゝに追つめ、馬よりとて引落し、散々に陵礫して、一々に髻をきる。
translation: The soldiers of the Six Provinces, waiting at the Pig Bear and the Kamo River, with over three hundred fully armed knights, surrounded the Emperor, and with a loud cry, they attacked from all sides.

original: 隨身十人が中、右の府生武基が髻もきられにけり。
translation: The attendants, who were to lead the way, were pursued there and there, pulled off their horses, and thoroughly trampled, each having their hair cut.

original: その中に、藤藏人大夫隆教が髻をきるとて、「是は汝が髻と思ふべからず、主の髻と思ふべし。」と、言ひ含めてきてけり。
translation: Among the ten attendants, the right attendant, Takehisa, had his hair cut.

original: 其後
translation: Among them, the chief of the Tsuchimikado, Ryuusuke, when his hair was cut, said, 'This is not your hair, but the master's hair.'

original: に御車の内へも、弓の筈つき入れなどして、簾かなぐり落し、御牛の鞦、
」と仰なりけれども、次でなければ御いましめもなし。
translation: "Though he said this, there was no punishment unless it was the next time.

original: 入道「神妙なり。」とぞのたまひける。
translation: The Lord said, 'It is indeed a sacred matter.'

original: 御車副には、因幡のさい使、鳥羽の國久丸といふをのこ、下臈なれども、なさけある者にて、泣々御車つかまつて、中御門の御所へ還御なし奉る。
translation: The attendants of the imperial carriage were the envoy from Inaba, the Lord of Toba, the National Governor of Kuni no Kuni, though a low-ranking official, a kind-hearted person who wept and held the imperial carriage, returning to the Middle Gate's palace.

original: 束帶の御袖にて、御涙をおさへつゝ、還御の儀式あさましさ、申すもなか／＼おろかなり。
translation: With the imperial sleeves tied in a belt, holding back tears, the return ceremony was solemn, and it was not easy to describe.

original: 大織冠、淡海公の御事は、擧げて申すに及ばず、忠仁公、昭宣公より以降、攝政關白の、かゝる御目にあはせ給ふ事、未だ承り及ばず。
translation: The matters of the Great Weaving Crown and the Lord of Awaji are too numerous to mention, and from the Lord of Chūnin and the Lord of Akizuki down to the Regent and Chancellor, no one has yet experienced such treatment.

original: 是こそ平家の惡行の始なれ。
translation: This is the beginning of the Heike's wicked deeds.

original: 小松殿こそ大に噪がれけれ。
translation: The Lord of Komatsu was greatly enraged.

original: 胸懸切りはなち散々にし散して、悦のときをつくり、六波羅へこそ參りけれ。
translation: Even in the imperial carriage, arrows were placed, the curtain was torn down, the horns of the ox were cut, the chest harness was torn apart, and in joy, they proceeded to the Six Provinces.

original: 「たとひ入道如何なる不思議を下知し給とも、など重盛に夢をば見せざりけるぞ。凡は資盛奇怪なり、旃檀は二葉よりかうばしとこそ見えたれ。已に十二三歳にならむずる者が、今は禮義を存知してこそ振舞ふべきに、かやうに尾籠を現じて、入道の惡名を立つ、不孝のいたり、汝一人にありけり。」とて、暫く伊勢の國に追ひ下さる。
translation: 'Even if the Lord gave such strange orders, why did he not show Shigemune a dream? The ordinary person, Yasutsune, is strange. The sandalwood tree, which is said to grow from two leaves, is seen here. Already twelve or thirteen years old, one should now know etiquette and act accordingly, but by showing such disgrace and establishing the Lord's bad name, this is the unfilial act of one person.' Thus, he was temporarily exiled to Ise Province.

original: 殿下、是をば夢にもしろしめさず、主上、明年御元服、御加冠、拜官の御定のために、御直盧に暫く御座あるべきにて、常の御出よりも引き繕はせ給ひ、今度は待賢門より入御あるべきにて、中御門を西へ御出なる。
translation: Afterward, the Lord of Komatsu was not informed, and those who were from the countryside, thinking that the Lord's words were the only ones to fear, gathered more than sixty people starting from the Lady of Namba, saying, 'On the twenty-first day, the Emperor's coronation will be held, so the Emperor will leave. Wait there, and when the attendants have their hair tied, Yasutsune's disgrace will be washed away.'

original: 猪熊堀川の邊に、六波羅の兵ども、直冑三百餘騎待ち受け奉り、殿下を中に取りこめ參らせて、前後より一度に、鬨をどとぞつくりける。
translation: The Emperor, not even dreaming of this, the Emperor, for the coronation and the appointment of officials, would stay at the imperial palace for a while, and this time would enter through the Gate of the Wise, proceeding west through the Middle Gate.

original: かゝる事よりして、人にはあざむかるゝぞ。
translation: From such matters, people are deceived.

original: 資盛朝臣、はふ／＼六波羅へおはして、祖父の相國禪門に、此由訴へ申されければ、入道大きに怒て、「縱ひ殿下なりとも、淨海があたりをば憚り給ふべきに、少者に左右なく、耻辱を與へられけるこそ遺恨の次第なれ。
translation: Yasutsune, greatly disgraced, fled to the Six Provinces and reported this to his grandfather, the Prime Minister Zenmon, who became very angry, saying, 'Even if it were the Emperor himself, the Pure Sea should have been cautious, but the young man had no attendants and was disgraced, which is a grievance.'

original: 殿下の御出ともいはず、一切下馬の禮義にも及ばず、驅け破て通らむとする間、暗さはくらし、つや／＼入道の孫とも知らず。
translation: Not even knowing that it was the Emperor's procession, they did not dismount, rushing through the darkness, not even recognizing the monk's grandson.

original: 御供の人々「何者ぞ、狼藉なり。御出なるに、乘物より下り候へ／＼。」と、云てけれども、餘に誇り勇み、世を世ともせざりける上、めし具したる侍ども、皆二十より内の若物共なり、禮義骨法辨へたる者一人もなし。
translation: The attendants said, 'Who is this? It is a disturbance. When the Emperor is leaving, you should dismount from your horse.' But, due to his pride and courage, and not considering the world's customs, the young retainers, all under twenty, had no one with knowledge of etiquette.

original: 資盛朝臣、大炊御門猪熊にて、殿下の御出に鼻突に參りあふ。
translation: Yasutsune, the court official, approached the pig bear at the Great Cook Gate, and rushed forward to meet the Emperor's procession.

original: 郁芳門より入御あるべきにて、東洞院を南へ、大炊御門を西へ御出なる。
translation: It was to enter through the Fragrant Gate, proceeding south to the East Palace, and west through the Great Cook Gate.

original: その時の御攝祿は、松殿にてましましけるが、中御門東洞院の御所より御參内ありけり。
translation: At that time, the imperial retinue was stationed at the pine palace, but there was a visit from the imperial residence at the Eastern Gate of the East Palace.

original: 枯野の景色まことに面白かりければ、わかき侍ども三十騎ばかりめし具して、蓮臺野や、紫野、右近馬場に打出でて、鷹どもあまたすゑさせ、鶉、雲雀をおたて／＼、終日にかり暮し、薄暮に及んで六波羅へこそ歸られけれ。
translation: The scenery of the withered fields was indeed fascinating, so thirty young retainers, equipped with provisions, rode out to the lotus fields, the Purple Field, and the Right Minister's Riding Ground, releasing many hawks, and hunting quails and sparrows, spending the whole day there, and returning to the Six Provinces at dusk.

original: 平家も又別して、朝家を恨み奉ることもなかりしほどに、世の亂れそめける根本は、去じ嘉應二年十月十六日に、小松殿の次男新三位中將資盛卿、その時はいまだ越前守とて十三になられけるが、雪ははだれに降たりけり。
translation: The Heike, too, did not harbor hatred for the imperial court, yet the root of the world's disorder was the day of the 16th of October in the second year of Kaya, when the second son of the Lord of Komatsu, the Third Rank Middle General Yasutsune, who was then the Governor of Echizen at thirteen years old, had snow fall upon him.

original: その後、入道相國小松殿には仰られもあはせず、片田舎の侍どものこはらかにて、入道殿の仰より外は、又恐しき事なしと思ふ者ども、難波妹尾を始として、都合六十餘人召し寄せ、「來二十一日、主上御元服の御定めの爲に殿下御出あるべかんなり。いづくにても待かけ奉り、前驅御隨身共が髻きて、資盛が耻雪げ。」とぞのたまひける。
translation: Thus, the retainers who were present were summoned, and said, 'From now on, you must be well aware. If you mistakenly report any disrespect to the Emperor, think carefully.'

original: これも世末になりて、王法の盡きぬる故なり。
translation: This is also due to the end of the world and the exhaustion of the laws of the heavens.

original: 清盛がかく心のまゝにふるまふこそ然るべからね。
translation: It would be proper for Kiyomori to act in accordance with his heart.

original: き。
貞盛、秀郷が、將門を討ち、頼義が貞任、宗任を亡し、義家が武平、家平を攻めたりしも、勸賞行はれしこと、受領には過ぎざり
translation: Though Masamune and Hidesato had defeated the Kiyomori, and Yorimasa had killed贞任 and 宗任, and Yoritomo had attacked 武平 and 家平, the rewards granted to them were not excessive.

original: 法皇も内々仰なりけるは、「昔より代々の朝敵を平ぐるもの多しといへども、いまだ加樣の事なし。
translation: The Emperor privately thought, 'Though there have been many who have subdued the enemies of the court from ancient times, there has never been a case like this.'

original: されども人の心の習なれば、猶飽きたらで、「あはれその人の亡びたらば、その國はあきなむ、その人失せたらば、その官にはなりなん。」など、疎からぬどちは、寄り合ひ寄り合ひさゝやきあへり。
