translation: They went to the great palace and sat at the edge of the North Mountain at the Cloud Forest Temple.

original: 大臣はか樣に宣て、小松殿へぞ歸られける。
translation: They left the monks at the temple and sent the attendants away, who returned home with their minds full of sorrow.

original: さる程に大納言のともなりつる侍ども、中御門烏丸の宿所へ走り歸て、此由申せば、北方以下の女房達、聲も惜まず泣叫ぶ。
translation: Now, only the young ones remained, and there was no one to question the matter. In the heart of the northern part, it was pitiful to think of it.

original: 「既に武士の向ひ候。少將殿を始參らせて、君達も捕れさせ給ふべしとこそ聞え候へ。急ぎ何方へも忍ばせ給へ。」と申ければ、「今は是程の身に成て、殘り留る身とても、安穩にて何かはせん。唯同じ一夜の露とも消ん事こそ本意なれ。さても今朝を限と知らざりける悲しさよ。」とて、臥まろびてぞ泣かれける。
translation: When he saw the shadow of the evening, he thought that the Minister of the Left's life would end that night, and it would be gone.

original: 已に武士共の近附よし聞えしかば、かくて又恥がましくうたてき目を見んもさすがなればとて、十に成給ふ女子、八歳の男子、車に取乘せ、何くを指共なくやり出す。
translation: Though there were many attendants, they did not even take anything, nor did they push the door.

original: 思召はなたじ者を。
translation: a man who summoned those who were not fit."

original: 如何樣にも、今夜首を刎られん事は、然べう候はず。
translation: The Minister of the Left declared in this way and returned to the Lord of the Court's residence.

original: 其後大臣中門に出て、侍共に宣けるは、「仰なればとて、大納言左右なう失ふ事有るべからず。入道腹のたちのまゝに、物噪き事し給ては、後に必悔しみ給ふべし。僻事してわれ恨な。」と宣へば、兵共、皆舌を振て恐慄く。
translation: Since the warriors had already approached, they felt ashamed to be seen, so they placed ten young women and an eight-year-old boy on the carriage and set off without delay.

original: 世の爲君の爲、家の爲の事を以て申候。
translation: The matter of the Hōgen War had not been long ago, and if one were to think of it, it would be terrifying.

original: 其儀では候はず。
translation: With this saying, after two years, the world was again in chaos, and the body of Shinkai, who had been buried, was dug up and his head was cut off and paraded through the streets.

original: か樣に親しく成て候へば、申とや思召され候らん。
translation: Thus, the ancients said, "If the death penalty is carried out, the rebellious will be cut off throughout the land."

original: 「人やある、人やある。」と召れければ、貞能參りたり。
translation: "There is someone, there is someone," they called, and贞能 arrived.

original: 道言せも果ず。
translation: The words were not yet finished.

original: 小松大臣は、其後遙に程歴て、嫡子權亮少將車のしりにのせつゝ、衞府四五人、隨身二三人召具して、兵一人も召具せられず、殊に大樣げで坐したり。
translation: The Minister of the Left, after traveling a long way, had his eldest son, the Right Minister of the Left, seated on the back of his carriage, with four or five guards and two or three attendants, without summoning even one soldier, and sat in a very grand manner.

original: 「如何にや。」と宣へば、その時見附奉り、うれしげに思はれたる氣色、地獄にて罪人共が、地藏菩薩を見奉るらんもかくやと覺えて哀なり。
translation: "How is this?" he said. At that moment, he was brought before him, and the expression on his face was one of joy, as if the sinners of hell were seeing the Bodhisattva of the Earth, which made him feel sorrowful.

original: 爰やらんとて開られたれば、大納言坐けり。
translation: Opening it, they found the Minister of the Left sitting there.

original: 是皆延喜の聖代、安和の御門の御僻事とぞ申傳へたる。
translation: These were all said to be the matters of the time of the Emperor's reign during the Engi and Anwa eras.

original: 各無實なりしか共、流罪せられ給ひにき。
translation: Though they were all without guilt, they were exiled.

original: 院中の人々、少將の袖をひかへ、袂にすがて名殘ををしみ、涙を流さぬはなかりけり。
translation: The people in the palace pulled at the general's sleeve and clung to his robe, filled with sorrow, and none could hold back their tears.

original: 良有てさてもあるべきならねば少將袖を顏に押當てゝ、泣々罷出られけり。
translation: Even though he was in good health, the general pressed his sleeve against his face and wept bitterly, then left.

original: 少將も涙に咽で申あぐる旨もなし。
translation: The general also did not say anything to console them.

original: 「何事にて候やらん、入道相國のきと西八條へ具し奉れと候と申せ。」といはせられたりければ、少將此事心得て、近習の女房達呼出し奉り、「夜邊何となう世の物騒う候しを、例の山法師の下るかと餘所に思て候へば、早成經が身の上にて候ひけり。大納言よさり斬らるべう候なれば、成經も同罪にてこそ候はんずらめ。今一度御所へ參て、君をも見まゐらせたう候へ共、既にかゝる身に罷成て候へば、憚存候。」とぞ申されける。
translation: "What is this matter?" they said, "It is said that the monk-chancellor has ordered you to prepare for your departure to the west at Yatsucho." Hearing this, the general understood the situation, and called his attendants and ladies-in-waiting, saying, "It is said that because of the disturbances in the world, people have been thinking that the mountain monks are descending. But this is indeed my own fate. If the Grand Chancellor is to be beheaded, then I, too, will be guilty of the same crime. I must go to the palace once more, and I will bring you as well. But now, having reached this state, I am too ashamed to do so."

original: 丹波少將成經は、其夜しも院の御所法住寺殿に上臥して、未出られざりけるに、大納言の侍共、急ぎ御所へ馳參て、少將殿を呼出し奉り、此由申に、「などや宰相の許より今まで告知せざるらん。」と、宣も果ねば、宰相殿よりとて使あり。
translation: The general of Tango, Naritsune, lay in the palace of the retired emperor at Hōjō-ji that night, not yet having left. The ministers of the Grand Chancellor hurried to the palace and summoned the general, saying, "How could the chancellor have not informed us of this until now?" The chancellor had sent a messenger.

original: 此宰相と申は、入道相國の弟也、宿所は六波羅の惣門の内なれば門脇の宰相とぞ申ける。
translation: This chancellor is the younger brother of the monk-chancellor. Since his residence was within the gates of Rokkō, he was called the Gate-side Chancellor.

original: 少將待受奉て、「さていかゞ候つる、」と申されければ、「入道餘に腹をたてて、教盛には終に對面もし給はず。叶ふまじき由頻に宣ひつれ共、出家入道まで申たればにやらん、暫く宿所に置奉れとの給ひつれども、始終よかるべしとも覺えず。」少將、「さ候へばこそ成經も御恩をもて、暫の命も延候はんずるにこそ。其につき候ては、大納言が事をばいかゞ聞召され候ぞ。」「其迄は思も寄ず。」と宣へば、其時涙をはら／＼と流いて、「誠に御恩を以てしばしの命もいき候はんずる事は然るべう候へども、命の惜う候も、父を今一度見ばやと思ふ爲也。大納言が斬れ候はんに於ては、成經とても、かひなき命を生て何にかはし候べき。唯一所でいかにもなる樣に、申てたばせ給ふべうや候らん。」と申されければ、宰相世にも苦げにて、「いさとよ、御邊の事をこそとかう申つれ。其までは思も寄ねども、大納言殿の御事をば、今朝内の大臣の樣々に申されければ、其も暫は心安い樣にこそ承はれ。」と宣へば、少將、泣々手を合てぞ悦れける。
translation: Then, as in the morning, they returned together in the same carriage.

original: ける。
translation: When Sugawara returned and told the chancellor, he said, "Ah, what a pity that one cannot have children. If I could not be related to my own child, I would be heartbroken."

original: 季貞参て、「宰相殿は早思召切て候ぞ。ともかうも能樣に御計ひ候へ。」と申ければ、入道、大に驚いて、「さればとて出家入道まではあまりにけしからず。其儀ならば、少將をば暫御邊に預奉ると云べし。」とこそ宣けれ。
translation: The general, upon receiving this, said, "What will happen now?" and the monk-chancellor replied, "The monk is angry and did not meet Kiyomori. He frequently issued orders, and even said that the general should be temporarily placed in his care. But I did not understand this at all. If the general's life is to be extended by the Emperor's grace, then I must know how the Grand Chancellor's affairs were handled." "I did not think of that," the general replied, and then wept, saying, "It is indeed true that the Emperor's grace will allow me to live for a little while longer. But I also feel the sorrow of my life, and I want to see my father once more. If the Grand Chancellor is to be beheaded, then Naritsune will also be a life that cannot be saved. I must say this to the Emperor, and I must be allowed to do so." The chancellor, with a sorrowful expression, said, "Please do so, for I have heard from the ministers this morning that the Grand Chancellor's affairs were handled. I now understand this, and I feel somewhat at ease." The general, weeping, clasped his hands in joy.

original: 季貞歸まゐて、宰相殿に此由申せば、「あはれ人の子をば持まじかりける物かな。我子の縁に結れざらむには、是程心をば碎じ物を。」とて出られけり。
translation: "If one is not a child, who would leave me behind and be so happy? True bonds are only found between parent and child. A child is something that belongs to another."

original: 少將、「痛な歎そ。宰相さて坐れば、命許はさり共乞請給はんずらん。」と、慰たまへども、人目もしらず、泣悶えけり。
translation: The general said, "This is indeed a painful lament. If the chancellor is to sit in judgment, I fear he will ask for your life." He tried to comfort her, but she wept in silence.

original: 「子ならざらむ者は、誰か唯今我身の上をさしおいて、是程までは悦べき。實の契は親子の中にぞ有ける。子をば人の持べかりける物哉。」とやがて思ぞ返されける。
translation: At the residence, the ladies-in-waiting felt as if a dead person had come back to life, and all of them were overjoyed and wept.

original: ず。
translation: "The general was left behind at the nearby house of the attendant, and the chancellor entered the gate.

original: 」と宣ふ間、其邊近き侍の家におろし置つゝ、宰相計ぞ門の内へは入給ふ。
translation: The general was surrounded by soldiers to protect him.

original: 少將をば、いつしか兵共打圍んで守護し奉る。
translation: The chancellor did not leave the general's side.

original: 「あはれ例の宰相が、物に心得ぬ。」とて、頓に返事もし給はず。
translation: The monk-chancellor said, "The new Grand Chancellor, Naritsune, has a plot to destroy this entire family and bring chaos to the world. This general is already the direct son of that Grand Chancellor. Whether distant or close, he is a relative, and it is not right to show leniency. If this rebellion is carried out, then even you must be punished. I will have him temporarily placed in the care of Kiyomori. If Kiyomori is in charge, then he will not be harmed."

original: 良有て入道宣けるは、「新大納言成親、此一門を滅して天下を亂むとする企あり。此少將は既に彼大納言が嫡子也。疎うもあれ、親うもあれ、えこそ申宥むまじけれ。若此謀反とげましかば、御邊とてもおだしうや御座べきと申せ。」とこそのたまひけれ。
translation: When Sugawara returned and reported this to the chancellor, he was truly filled with regret and said, "Since the Hōgen and Heiji rebellions, I have always been ready to sacrifice my life for the Emperor. In the future, I will also be prepared to guard against any wind that may come. Even if Kiyomori is old, if there are many young children, how can one side be secure? If you say that Naritsune is to be temporarily placed in Kiyomori's care, then you must suspect Kiyomori of having two minds. If you act in such a way, it will be a great shame for the world. Now, I will grant him time to leave, to become a monk, and live in a mountain village, devoting himself to the pursuit of enlightenment. This is a sorrowful matter. If one is in the world, one must hope; if one's hopes are not fulfilled, one must resent. It is only by hating this sorrowful world that one can enter the true path."

original: 少將御所を罷出つるより、流るゝ涙つきせぬに、北方の有樣を見給ひてはいとゞ爲方なげにぞ見えられける。
translation: As the general left the palace, his tears did not dry, and looking at the north, he appeared very pitiful.

original: 「あは此等が内々謀し事の漏にけるよ。」と思召すにあさまし。
translation: "This is indeed a secret plot that has leaked out," he thought, and it was most disgraceful.

original: 「さるにても是へ。」と御氣色有ければ、參られたり。
translation: "Even so, it is this way," he said, and he went to see them.

original: 舅の宰相の許へ出られたれば、北方は近う産すべき人にて御座けるが、今朝より此歎を打添て、已に命も消入る心地ぞせられける。
translation: When the general left for the chancellor's residence, the north was near where the person who would give birth to him was, but since this morning, he had been filled with sorrow, and his life had already been lost in his heart.

original: 季貞歸参て、此由宰相殿に申ければ、誠に本意なげにて、重て申されけるは、「保元平治より以降、度々の合戰にも、御命に代り参らせんとこそ存候へ。此後もあらき風をば、先防ぎ参らせ候はんずるに、縱教盛こそ年老て候とも、若き子供數多候へば、一方の御固にはなどか成で候べき。それに成經暫預らうと申を、御容れ無きは、教盛を一向二心ある者と思召にこそ。是程後めたう思はれ参らせては、世に有ても何にかはし候べき。今は只身の暇を賜て、出家入道し、片山里に籠て、一筋に後世菩提の勤を營み候はん。由なき憂世の交なり。世にあればこそ望もあれ、望の叶はねばこそ恨もあれ。しかじ憂世を厭ひ、眞の道に入なんには。」とぞ宣
translation: When Sugawara returned and said, "The chancellor has already decided quickly. He has made a wise plan." The monk-chancellor was greatly surprised and said, "Even so, it is too much to ask him to become a monk. If that were the case, the general should be temporarily placed in your care."

original: 法皇も御
translation: The Emperor also wept.

original: 女房達御前へ參り、此由奏せられければ、法皇大に驚かせ給て、さればこそ今朝の入道相國が使に早御心得あり。
translation: When the ladies-in-waiting presented this to the Emperor, he was greatly surprised. Hence, this morning, the monk-chancellor's messenger had come early, and the Emperor had already understood the matter.

original: 丹波少將には舅なり。
translation: The general of Tango was the husband of the chancellor.

original: 涙を流させ給ひて、仰下さるゝ旨もなし。
translation: He did not say anything to console them.

original: 法皇は後を遙に御覽じ送らせ給ひて、末代こそ心憂けれ、是かぎりで又御覽ぜぬ事もやあらんずらんとて、御涙を流させ給ぞ忝き。
translation: The Emperor, looking after him as he left, said, "May you be troubled in your heart for the rest of your days. I fear that I shall never see you again," and wept bitterly.

original: 憑れつる宰相殿には離れ給ひぬ。
translation: The general's heart was filled with despair.

original: 少將の心の中、さこそは便無りけめ。
translation: The chancellor remained at the middle gate and did not face the general directly.

original: 宰相中門に居給ひたれば、入道對面もし給はず。
translation: The chief minister, Minister Sugawara no Michikaze, was summoned and said, "Though I have no relation to the matter, I regret it deeply. But I cannot do anything. If I had allowed this person to be entrusted with matters, I would not have been so troubled. Since this morning, the lament has been so great that I fear his life has already been lost. He is surely in pain. I will have the general temporarily placed in the care of Kiyomori. If Kiyomori is in charge, then he will not be harmed."

original: 源大夫判官季貞をもて申入られけるは、「由なき者に親うなて、返々悔しう候へども、甲斐も候はず。相具せさせて候者の、此程惱む事の候なるが、今朝より此歎を打そへては既に命も絶なんず。何かはくるしう候べき。少將をば暫く教盛に預させおはしませ。教盛かうて候へば、なじかは僻事せさせ候べき。」と申されければ、季貞参て此由申す。
translation: "Ah, the usual chancellor does not understand the matter," the emperor said, and did not respond immediately.

original: 「御乳に参り始候らひて、君をちの中より抱上参て、月日の重なるに隨ひて、我身の年の行をば歎ずして、君の成人しう成せ給ふ事をのみうれしう思ひ奉り、白地とは思へども、既に二十一年、片時も離れ参らせず。院内へ参らせ給ひて、遲う出させ給ふだにも、覺束なう思ひ参らするに、如何なる御目にか遭せ給はんずらん。」と泣く。
translation: "Since I began to nurse you, I took you from the middle of the palace and brought you up. As the days passed, I sighed at my own advancing age, and only rejoiced at your growth. Though I did not think of you as my own, I had not left your side for twenty-one years. When I brought you into the palace, I was late in doing so, and I was very anxious about what you might have to endure."

original: 西八條近うなて、車を停め、先案内を申入られければ、太政入道「丹波少將をば此内へは入らるべから
translation: When they approached West Yatsucho and stopped the carriage, the attendants were instructed to lead the way. The chief minister said, "The general of Tango must not enter here."

original: 保元平治より以來、平家の人々、樂榮えのみ有て、愁歎はなかりしに、此宰相計こそ、由なき聟ゆゑに、かゝる歎をばせられけれ。
translation: Since the time of the Hōgen and Heiji rebellions, the people of the Heike had only known happiness and no sorrow, but this chancellor, because of his inconsiderate son-in-law, was now suffering such sorrow.

original: 西八條殿より、使しきなみに有ければ、宰相「行むかうてこそ、ともかうも成め。」とて出給へば少將も宰相の車の後に乘てぞ出られける。
translation: Since a messenger had come from the West Yatsucho, the chancellor said, "Let us go, then," and left. The general also rode in the wake of the chancellor's carriage.

original: 少將乳母に六條と云女房あり。
translation: The general had a nurse named Rokkō.

original: 世を靜めん程、
translation: To bring peace to the world,

original: 法皇を鳥羽の北殿へ移奉るか、然らずは、是へまれ、御幸をなし参らせんと思ふは如何に。
translation: Should the Emperor be moved to the northern hall of the Bird's Nest Palace, or if not, should he be brought here and the imperial visit be carried out? What do you think?

original: 其儀ならば、北面の輩、箭をも一つ射んずらん。
translation: If such a plan is carried out, the people of the north would certainly shoot an arrow.

original: 』とこそ見えて候へ。
translation: If the Minister Narichika is not summoned, even if the Emperor has any strange thoughts, there is nothing to fear.

original: 是非の理誰か能く定べき。
translation: Like a ring, it has no end.

original: 爰を以て縱人怒ると云とも、かへて我咎を懼れよ。
translation: However, because the Emperor's fortune has not yet ended, the rebellion has been revealed.

original: 環の如くして端なし。
相共に賢愚なり。
translation: Therefore, even if one says, "Let the people be angry," one should fear one's own guilt.

original: 然れば君の思召立ところ、道理半無に非ず。
translation: Among them, this family has, for generations, put down the enemies of the court and calmed the waves of the four seas, a loyalty without equal. Yet, to boast of this merit as if it were nothing is unacceptable.

original: 中にも此一門は、代々の朝敵を平げて、四海の逆浪を靜る事は無雙の忠なれ共、其賞に誇る事は傍若無人共申つべし。
translation: The Seventeen Articles of Prince Shōtoku's Constitution state: "All people have hearts, and each has their own views. They consider others wrong and themselves right, and vice versa. Who can determine the right or wrong?"

original: 聖徳太子十七箇條の御憲法に『人皆心有り、必各執あり、彼を是し我を非し、我を是し彼を非す。
translation: The principles of right and wrong are not clear-cut; people are alike in wisdom and foolishness.

original: 君と臣とを比るに親疎別く方なし。
translation: [2] In Nihon Koten Bungaku Taikei (Tokyo: Iwanami Shoten, 1957, vol. 32; hereafter cited as NKBT), it reads: "Chikuzen no kami Masanobu, kuranji no chokutare ni."

original: 神明佛陀感應あらば、君も思召なほす事などか候はざるべき。
translation: When the principles of reason and the ways of the world are compared, one should adhere to the principles of reason.

original: 所當の罪科行れん上は、退いて事の由を陳じ申させ給て、君の御爲には彌奉公の忠勤を盡し、民の爲には益撫育の哀憐を致させ給はば、神明の加護に預り佛陀の冥慮に背べからず。
translation: There is no distinction between the closeness or distance between the Emperor and his ministers.

original: 其上仰合せらるゝ成親卿を召置れぬる上は、縱君如何なる不思議を思召し立せ給ふとも、何の恐か候べき。
translation: If the gods and the Buddha respond to the prayers, the Emperor should not be so blinded as to think that his will is the only one that matters.

original: 然れ共御運盡ざるに依て、御謀反已に露ぬ。
translation: If the appropriate punishment is to be carried out, the matter should be explained, and the Emperor should be asked to fulfill his duty to the Emperor with loyalty, and to the people with compassion. Then, with the help of the gods and the wisdom of the Buddha, the matter can be resolved.

original: て見えけるを藏さうと、頻に衣の胸を引ちがへ引ちがへぞし給ひける。
translation: The Minister took his seat beside Minister Kiyomori.

original: 大臣は舎弟宗盛卿の座上につき給ふ。
translation: The Chief Minister did not make any proclamation, and the Minister did not speak either.

original: きせながとり出せ。
translation: Bring out the bow.

original: 馬に鞍おかせよ。
translation: Put the saddle on the horse.

original: 」とぞ宣ける。
translation: "Thus did he proclaim.

original: 其に成親と云ふ無用の徒者、西光と云下賤の不當人めが申す事に附かせ給て、此一門を滅すべき由、法皇の御結構こそ遺恨の次第なれ。
translation: It was through the words of the useless man known as Narichika, who followed the inappropriate words of the low-born man Seikō, that the matter of destroying this clan was proposed, and this became the source of the Emperor's resentment.

original: 朝敵となて後は、いかに悔ゆとも益あるまじ。
translation: Once branded as an enemy of the court, no amount of regret will be of any benefit.

original: 此後も讒奏する者あらば、當家追討の院宣下されつと覺るぞ。
translation: If there are any further slanderers, the imperial decree will be issued to pursue and punish the family.

original: 先世に四恩あり。
translation: The debt to heaven and earth, the debt to the king, the debt to one's parents, and the debt to all sentient beings—these are they.

original: 天地の恩、國王の恩、父母の恩、衆生の恩是也。
translation: Among these, the debt to the Emperor is the heaviest.

original: 夫三世の諸佛解脱幢相の法衣を脱捨て、忽に甲冑を鎧ひ、弓箭を帶しましまさむ事、内には既に破戒無慙の罪を招くのみならず、外には又仁義禮智信の法にも背き候なんず。
translation: Though this is a matter of great concern, it is not appropriate to leave the meaning of the heart behind.

original: 旁々恐ある申事にて候へども、心の底に旨趣を殘すべきに非ず。
translation: There are four great debts in previous lives.

original: 其中に最重きは朝恩也。
translation: There is no place in the world that is not the Emperor's domain.

original: 入道も宣ひ出さず、大臣も申しいださるゝ事もなし。
translation: What the Chief Minister said was, "Minister Narichika's rebellion is not a matter of course, but is entirely due to the Emperor's will. To bring peace to the world, should the Emperor be moved to the northern hall of the Bird's Nest Palace, or if not, should he be brought here and the imperial visit be carried out? What do you think?" When the Minister heard this, he wept profusely.

original: 入道、「如何に／＼。」とあきれ給ふ。
translation: The Minister, restraining his tears, said, "By hearing this, I realize that the Emperor's fortune will soon come to an end.

original: 良有て入道のたまひけるは、「成親卿が謀反は事の數にもあらず。一向法皇の御結構にて在けるぞや。世をしづめん程、法皇を鳥羽の北殿へ遷奉るか、然らずば、是へまれ、御幸を成まゐらせんと思ふは如何に。」と宣へば、大臣聞も敢ず、はら／＼とぞ泣れける。
translation: The Chief Minister said in surprise, "How so?"

original: 旗竿共引そばめ／＼、馬の腹帶を固め、甲の緒を縮め、唯今皆打立んずる氣色共なるに、小松殿烏帽子直衣に、大文の指貫のそば取て、さやめき入給へば、事の外にぞ見えられける。
translation: The banners were raised, the horse's girths were tightened, and the armor straps were fastened. All were prepared for action. When the Minister of Kōmatsu, wearing a black cap and a plain robe, stepped in with a large ribbon tied around his finger, he stood out clearly from the rest.

original: 所謂重盛が無才愚闇の身をもて、蓮府槐門の位に至る。
translation: In addition, half of the provinces and regions were granted to this family as their domain, and all the fields and villages were under their control.

original: 何に況、先祖にも未聞ざし太政大臣を極めさせ給ふ。
translation: So it was that the man known as Shigemasa, with his dull and foolish nature, reached the position of Minister of the Interior.

original: たとひ人何と申す共、七代までは此一門をば爭でか捨させ給べき。
translation: Even if people say what they will, for seven generations, this clan should not have been allowed to be destroyed through conflict.

original: 是一の奉公也。
translation: This is a matter of service to the Emperor.

original: 次に平治元年十二月、信頼義朝が院内を取奉り、大内にたて籠り天下黒闇と成しに、入道身を捨て、凶徒を追落し、經宗惟方を召縛しに至まで、既に君の御爲に命を失んとする事度度に及ぶ。
translation: Next, in the twelfth month of the first year of Heiji, Yoshitoki, the trusted son of Yoshitaka, took control of the court and occupied the Great Interior. He was surrounded in the Great Interior and the world was plunged into darkness. The Chief Minister gave up his life, chased away the bandits, and even summoned and bound the monk Keisō and the priest Yoshimasa. He had already sacrificed his life for the Emperor on many occasions.

original: 保元に平右馬助を始として、一門半過て、新院の御方へ参にき。
translation: Starting with the Right Minister Hira no Masayoshi in the year of Hōgen, the entire clan had passed through many generations, and had eventually come to serve the Emperor at the Imperial Court.

original: 一宮の御事は、故刑部卿殿の養君にて坐いしかば、旁々見放ち参らせ難かしども、故院の御遺誡に任て、御方にて先を懸たりき。
translation: The matter of the First Shrine was entrusted to the late Minister of Justice, who had been raised as his heir. Although it was difficult to attend to matters from the side, the matter was handled in accordance with the late Emperor's instructions, and the matter was entrusted to the Emperor's side first.

original: 其外諸國の受領衞府諸司などは、縁に居溢れ、庭にもひしと竝居たり。
translation: Outside, officials from various provinces and regions filled the corridors and the courtyard was crowded with people.

original: 門前にて車よりおり、門の内へ指入て見給へば、入道腹卷を著給ふ上は一門の卿相雲客數十人、各色々の直垂に、思々の鎧著て、中門の廊に二行に著座せられたり。
translation: When he stepped out of the carriage at the gate and looked inside, he saw that the Chief Minister, wearing a waist sash, was seated with several dozen officials of the First Court, each wearing different robes and armor, in two rows along the corridor of the central gate.

original: 「あは早成親卿が首を刎られたるな。」と宣へば、「さは候はねども、入道殿御著背長召され候。侍共も皆打立て法住寺殿へ寄んと出たち候。法皇をば鳥羽殿へ押籠参らせうと候が、内々は鎭西の方へ流し参らせうと被擬候。」と申せば、大臣、爭かさる事在べきと思へ共、今朝の禪門の氣色、さる物狂しき事もあるらむとて、車を飛して、西八條へぞおはしたる。
translation: "Ah, it is said that the head of Minister Narichika has been cut off." When he announced this, the Minister replied, "Indeed, but the Chief Minister has summoned the Emperor to appear. The attendants have all gathered and are proceeding to the Hōjū-ji Palace. The Emperor is to be moved to the Bird's Nest Palace, but secretly, it is planned to move him to the western provinces." Hearing this, the Minister thought there might be a conflict, but considering the strange atmosphere of the morning at the Zen Gate, he hurried to the western Hachijōyama in a carriage.

original: やゝあて入道宣けるは、「貞能、此事如何思ふ。
translation: The Chief Minister then said, "Masanobu, what do you think of this matter?"

original: [2]筑後守貞能は木蘭地の直垂に緋縅の鎧著て、御前に畏て候。
translation: Minister Masanobu, the Governor of Chikuzen Province, was dressed in a robe with a camellia pattern and a crimson sash, and stood before the ruler in reverence.

original: 貞能を召す。
translation: Summon the Minister Masanobu.

original: 其氣色大方ゆゝしうぞ見えし。
translation: His demeanor appeared very composed.

original: 既に赤地の錦の直垂に、黒絲縅の腹卷の、白金物打たる胸板せめて、先年安藝守たりし時、神拜の次に、靈夢を蒙て、嚴島の大明神より現に賜はられたりける銀の蛭卷したる小長刀、常の枕を放ず立られたりしを脇挾み、中門の廊へぞ出られける。
translation: He was dressed in a red silk robe, with a black silk sash wrapped around his waist, and a white metal-plated chest plate. He wore a small long sword with a silver worm-shaped hilt, which had been granted by the Great Deity of Ise Shrine when he was the Governor of Aki Province, and which he had carried with him since that time. He had not laid it aside even when resting, and thus carried it at his side as he stepped out onto the corridor of the central gate.

original: 普天の下王地に非ずと云ふ事なし。
translation: Therefore, even the wise men who washed their ears in the waters of the Yōgawa River and broke a fern on the Shōyō Mountains knew that it was a matter of etiquette not to defy the Emperor's decree.

original: さればかの頴川の水に耳を洗ひ、首陽山に蕨を折し賢人も、勅命背き難き禮儀をば存知すとこそ承はれ。
translation: How much more so, when the Emperor has granted the position of Chief Minister to one whose ancestors have never heard of such a title.

original: 大臣涙を抑て申されけるは、「此仰承候に、御運は早末に成ぬと覺候。
translation: When the fate of a person turns, it is certain that evil deeds will be planned.

original: 人の運命の傾んとては、必惡事を思立候也。
translation: Moreover, the Emperor's condition will not be improved.

original: 又御有樣、更現共覺候はず。
translation: Even though our era is said to be at the edge of the land and scattered, the descendants of the sun goddess, as the rulers of the country, from the time of Amaterasu's descendants, who governed the morning affairs, to those who have reached the position of Chief Minister, have not failed to wear armor and observe proper etiquette.

original: さすが我朝は邊地粟散の境と申ながら、天照大神の御子孫、國の主として、天兒屋根命の末、朝の政を司どり給ひしより以降、太政大臣の官に至る人の、甲冑をよろふ事禮儀を背にあらずや。
translation: Among them, the Emperor has taken the path of monastic life.

original: 就中に御出家の御身なり。
translation: Thus, the robe of the Buddha, which represents the liberation of the three worlds, has been cast aside, and he has suddenly put on armor, and carried bow and arrow. This not only invites the sin of breaking the precepts and being shameless, but also violates the laws of humanity, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and faith.

original: 入道ふし目に成て、あはれ例の内府が、世をへうする樣に振舞、大に諫ばやとこそ思はれけめども、さすが子ながらも、内には五戒を保て慈悲を先とし、外には五常を亂らず、禮儀を正しうし給ふ人なれば、あの姿に腹卷を著て向はむ事、面はゆう辱しうや思はれけん、障子を少し引立て、素絹の衣を腹卷の上に、周章著に著給たりけるが、胸板の金物の少しはづれ
translation: The Chief Minister, with a stern expression, acted in a manner as if the former Minister of the Interior were managing the affairs of the world, which was a great act of remonstration. Yet, despite this, he was a man who, within, kept the Five Precepts and placed compassion first, and outwardly did not violate the Five Constants, maintaining proper etiquette. Thus, the sight of him, wearing a waist sash and facing them, was a great humiliation. He slightly pulled aside the shoji screen and wore a plain silk robe over his waist sash, but due to the embarrassment, he constantly pulled at the front of his robe to cover the metal decoration on his chest plate.

original: 是希代の朝恩に非ずや。
translation: Now, forgetting such a great favor, the Emperor has turned against the Emperor,

original: 今是等の莫大の御恩を思召忘れて、猥しく法皇
translation: which is a violation of the will of the gods of the sun and the Great Shrine of Hachiman.

original: 主馬判官盛國、急ぎ小松殿へ馳參て、「世は既にかう候。」と申ければ、大臣聞も敢ず。
translation: The Chief Steward, Masanori, hurried to the Kōmatsu Palace and said, "The world is already in this state." When the Minister heard this, he responded with a nod.

original: 加之國郡半過て一門の所領と成、田園悉く一家の進止たり。
translation: This was not an ordinary imperial favor.

original: を傾け参らせ給はん事、天照大神、正八幡宮の神慮にも背き候ひなんず。
translation: Japan is a land of the gods.

original: 太政入道は、か樣に人々數多縛め置ても、猶心行ずや思はれけん。
translation: Though the Chief Minister had bound so many people, he still felt the unrest in his heart.

original: 神は非禮を受給はず。
translation: Therefore, the Emperor's decision is not without reason.

original: 日本は是神國也。
translation: The gods do not accept improper treatment.

original: 大方は入道院方の奉公思切たり。
translation: Generally, the attendants were devoted to the service of the Chief Minister.

original: 侍共にその用意せよと觸べし。
translation: He ordered the attendants to prepare accordingly.

original: 或時隣國より凶賊起て、幽王の都を攻けるに、烽火をあぐれ共、例の后の火に慣て、兵も参らず。
translation: After doing this repeatedly, no one came anymore.

original: 其時都傾て、幽王終に亡にき。
translation: At one time, a band of robbers rose from a neighboring country and attacked King You's capital. When the beacon fires were raised, the soldiers, accustomed to the usual fires, did not come.

original: 」とて、皆歸されけり。
translation: Go back quickly.

original: 疾う／＼歸れ。
translation: However, this matter was considered a trivial one.

original: さてこの后は野干と成て走失けるぞ怖き。
translation: At that time, the capital fell, and King You ultimately died.

original: か樣の事在なれば、自今以後も、是より召んには、みなかくの如くに参るべし。
translation: Then, this concubine became a wild dog and ran away, which was very terrifying.

original: 「果報こそ目出たうて、大臣の大將にこそ至らめ。容儀帶佩人に勝れ、才智才學さへ世に超たるべしやは。」とぞ時の人々感じ合れける。
translation: Upon hearing of this, the Emperor said, "Though it has not yet begun, the Inner Minister's heart is indeed ashamed. He has been rewarded with kindness."

original: 君の此由聞召て、「今に始ぬ事なれ共、内府が心の中こそ愧しけれ。あたをば恩を以て報ぜられたり。」とぞ仰ける。
translation: "Though the ruler may not be a ruler, the subject must not be below the subject; though the father may not be a father, the son must not be without filial piety. Loyalty to the ruler, and filial piety to the father."

original: 「君雖不君、不可臣以下臣、父雖不父不可子以不子。君の爲には忠有て、父の爲には孝あれ。」と文宣王の宣けるに不違。
translation: In truth, even though he had not heard of it, he obeyed the words of his father who had advised him. He knew the extent of his own power, whether it was present or not. Though he did not intend to fight, he had planned to comply with the Minister's scheme of rebellion.

original: 實にはさせる事をも聞出されざりけれ共父を諫め被申つる詞に順ひ、我身に勢の著か、著ぬかの程をも知り、又父子軍をせんとにはあらねども、角して入道相國の謀反の志も和げ給ふとの謀也。
translation: "With that, they all returned."

original: され共此事聞直しつ、僻事にてありけり。
translation: Shigemasa had heard of this strange matter and summoned them.

original: 重盛不思議の事を聞出して召つるなり。
translation: Because of such an event, from now on, if summoned, everyone should come as they did before.

original: 諸候來に寇なし。
translation: King You, finding this amusing, often raised the beacon fires.

original: 幽王嬉き事にして、其事となう、常に烽火を擧給ふ。
translation: After that, every time she smiled, a hundred beauties were given to her.

original: 然れば院中に参り籠り候べし。
translation: Therefore, I shall enter the Imperial Court and remain there.

original: 只今侍一人に仰附て、御坪の内に引出されて、重盛が首の刎られん事は、易い程の事でこそ候へ。
translation: Hear this well.

original: 何迄か命生て、亂れん世をも見候べき。
translation: Only Shigemasa, who was born in the later generations, is destined to face such a sorrowful fate.

original: 痛哉、不孝の罪を遁れんとすれば、君の御爲に已に不忠の逆臣と成ぬべし。
translation: One is caught between a rock and a hard place.

original: 是等を召具して、院の御所法住寺殿を守護しまゐらせ候はば、さすが以の外の御大事でこそ候はんずらめ。
translation: Alas, if one serves with loyalty for the sake of the Emperor, even the highest peak of Mount Meru would not be higher than the father's kindness, which is suddenly forgotten.

original: 少候らん。
translation: If these are summoned and the Imperial Palace at Hōjō-ji Temple is guarded, it would be an extraordinary matter, even beyond the usual great affairs.

original: 其儀にて候はば、重盛が身に代り、命に代らんと契りたる侍共、少
translation: If this is done, then the retainers who have sworn to take Shigemasa's place and even his life shall wait a little.

original: 悲哉、君の御爲に奉公の忠を致んとすれば、迷盧八萬の頂より猶高き父の恩忽に忘れんとす。
translation: Painful indeed, if one seeks to escape the sin of filial disobedience, then one would already be a disloyal traitor to the Emperor.

original: か樣の先蹤を思ふにも、富貴と云ひ、榮花と云ひ、朝恩と云ひ、重職と云ひ、旁極させ給ぬれば、御運の盡ん事難かるべきに非ず。
translation: How long will life be granted, to witness such a chaotic world?

original: 其恩の重き事を思へば、千顆萬顆の玉にも越え、其恩の深き色を案ずれば、一入再入の紅にも過たらん。
translation: Considering the weight of this favor, it surpasses even a thousand or ten thousand pearls; and considering the depth of this kindness, it exceeds even the red of a double entry.

original: 是は君の御理にて候へば、叶はざらむまでも院御所法住寺殿を守護し参らせ候べし。
translation: If this is your will, then even if it is not possible, I shall guard the Imperial Palace at Hōjō-ji Temple.

original: 法皇仰参らせん事も、はや思とゞまり、腹卷脱おき、素絹の衣に袈裟打掛て、最心にも起らぬ念誦してこそ坐しけれ。
translation: Not a single person carried a bow or arrow.

original: 異國にさる
translation: The Emperor's intention to ascend was already decided, so he removed his belt, put on a plain silk robe with a Buddhist robe over it, and sat in deep meditation without even moving his heart.

original: 小松殿には、盛國承て著到附けり。

original: 馳参たる勢共、一萬餘騎とぞ註いたる。
translation: Jōnō wept, saying, "It is only natural to rely on people. This is a matter of contention. All these things that were said will be regretted."

original: 著到披見の後、大臣中門に出て侍共に宣けるは、日比の契約を違へずして参たるこそ神妙なれ。

original: ためし有り。
translation: At the Kōmatsu Palace, Shigemasa had already arrived.

original: 「朧げにては噪がせ給はぬ人の、かゝる披露の有は別の仔細のあるにこそ。」と、皆物具して我も／＼と馳参る。
translation: He summoned the Judge of the Chief Steward, Shigemasa, and said, "Shigemasa, you must investigate the affairs of the state. Those who think of themselves as themselves, let them all come forth with their belongings and rush to me."

original: 主馬判官盛國を召て、「重盛こそ天下の大事を別して聞出したれ。我を我と思はん者共は、皆物具して馳参れと披露せよ。」と宣へば、此由披露す。
translation: "With that, he returned to the Kōmatsu Palace."

original: 」とて、小松殿へぞ歸られける。

translation: From this morning onward,

translation: I think such things will be quiet, but while there is still noise, I have returned.

original: 淀、羽束師、宇治、岡屋、日野、勸修寺、醍醐、小栗栖、梅津、桂、大原、靜原、芹生の里に溢居たる兵共或は鎧著て、未甲を著ぬもあり、或は矢負て未弓を持たぬもあり。
translation: The reason for this revelation is that there is a special matter.

original: 片鐙蹈や蹈まずにて、周章噪いで馳参る。
translation: So, they all came forth with their belongings, rushing to him.

original: 小松殿に噪ぐ事ありと聞えしかば、西八條に數千騎ありける兵共、入道にかうとも申も入ず、さざめき連て、皆小松殿へぞ馳たりける。
translation: Soldiers overflowed in the villages of Yodo, Hashijiru, Uji, Okayama, Hino, Kōshū-ji, Tōgō, Koshikibari, Umezono, Katsura, Ōhara, Shizunai, and Serigawa. Some wore armor, some did not wear helmets, some carried arrows but did not have bows.

original: 少しも弓箭に携る程の者は一人も殘ず。
translation: They rushed forward, one leg on the stirrup, in confusion and noise.

original: 其時入道大に驚き、貞能を召て、「内府は何と思ひて、是等をば呼とるやらん。是で言つる樣に、入道が許へ討手などや向んずらん。」と宣へば、貞能涙をはら／＼と流いて「人も人にこそ依せ給ひ候へ。爭かさる御事候べき。これにて申させ給ひつる事共も、皆御後悔ぞ候らん。」と申ければ、入道、内府に中違うては、惡かりなんとや思はれけん。
translation: Hearing that there was noise at the Kōmatsu Palace, the thousands of soldiers at Nishi-Hachijō, without even asking the monk, rushed in a commotion to the Kōmatsu Palace.

original: さらば人参れ。
translation: As for serving as an attendant to the Emperor, you shall act upon seeing Shigemasa's neck being taken.

original: 力もなげにて、「いや／＼是迄は思も寄さうず。惡黨共が申す事につかせ給ひて、僻事などや出こむずらんと思ふ計でこそ候へ。」とのたまへば、大臣、「縱如何なる僻事出來候とも、君をば何とかし参らせ給ふべき。」とて、つい立て中門に出で侍共に仰られけるは、「唯今重盛が申しつる事をば、汝等承ずや。
translation: The Minister said, "Even if any such trivial matters arise, I shall somehow manage to serve the Emperor."

original: 寇なければ即ち去ぬ。
translation: The feudal lords came, but there was no enemy.

original: 加樣にする事度々に及べば、参る者も無りけり。
translation: If there was no enemy, they would immediately leave.

original: 「國に諫る臣あれ
translation: "The reward is indeed remarkable, reaching the position of Grand Minister and General. His appearance and attire surpass others, and his wisdom and learning are beyond the world."

original: ば、其國心安く、家に諫る子あれば、其家必たゞし。
translation: "Thus, the people of the time felt."

original: 」と云へり。
translation: "If there is a minister who advises the country, the country will be cheap; if there is a son who advises the family, the family will certainly be in order."

original: 上古にも末代にも有がたかりし大臣なり。
translation: "Thus it was said."

original: じと云最愛の后をもち給へり。
translation: After inspecting those who had arrived, the Minister went out through the middle gate and said to those who were guarding it, "Those who have come without breaking the agreement of Hibi are the most devout."

original: 異國の習には、天下に兵革起る時、所々に火を擧げ、大鼓を撃て、兵を召す謀有り。
translation: However, when King You's heart was not pleased, Bao would not smile, and so she never smiled afterward.

original: かの蕭何は大功かたへに越たるに依て、官大相國に至り、劔を帶し沓を履ながら殿上に昇る事を許されしか共、叡慮に背く事あれば、高祖重う警て、深う罪せられにき。
translation: Even thinking of such precedents, wealth, honor, imperial favor, and high office, if they are taken to extremes, will not be without the end of one's fortune.

original: 院参の御供をも仕るべからず。
translation: Xiao He, who had great merit, rose to the position of Grand Chancellor, and was allowed to ascend to the court with sword and sandals, but when he acted against the wisdom of the emperor, Emperor Gaozu warned him severely and punished him greatly.

original: 進退惟谷れり。
translation: It is indeed very difficult to decide what to do.

original: 周の幽王、褒
translation: The force that rushed there numbered over ten thousand.

original: 院中をも守護し参らすべからず。
translation: One must not serve as an attendant to the Emperor.

translation: In the end, the only thing to be requested is that Shigemasa's neck be taken.

original: 申請る所詮は、唯重盛が頸を召され候へ。
translation: One must not go to guard the Imperial Court.

original: 同六月二日、新大納言成親卿をば、公卿の座へ出し奉て、御物参せたりけれども、胸せき塞て、御箸をだにもたてられず。
十二郡を割分て後は、出羽國にや候らん。
translation: Although it may be far, the distance between Bizen and Bitchū provinces can be covered in two or three days.

original: 日ごろはわかき人にて君達などの事もさしも濃にも坐ざりしか共、今はの時になりしかば、さすが心にやかゝられけん。
translation: Although he had previously treated the affairs of you all with little concern, now that the time had come, it surely touched his heart.

original: 近江中將入道蓮淨佐渡國、山城守基兼伯耆國、式部大輔正綱播磨國、宗判官信房阿波國、新平判官資行は美作國とぞ聞えし。
translation: The Lord of Omi, Enryaku Shōnin, was dispatched to Sado Province; the Governor of Yamashiro, Kiyomasa, to Bingo Province; the Assistant Minister of the Bureau of Rites, Masanori, to Harima Province; the Judge Zōpan, Shigeyoshi, to Awa Province; and the Judge Shinpei, Yasuharu, to Bizen Province, it was said.

original: 同廿二日福原へ下著給ひたりければ、太政入道瀬尾太郎兼康に仰て、備中國へぞ流されける。
translation: On the twenty-second day, he descended to Fukuhara, and ordered the Lord of the Left, Sei, Masakazu, to send him to Bizen Province.

original: 夜晝只佛の御名をのみ唱て父の事をぞ嘆かれける。
translation: Day and night, he only chanted the name of the Buddha, lamenting his father's fate.

translation: Yet, the Lord of Tango did not offer any comfort.

original: 其は兩國が一國なりし時詠侍る歌なり。
translation: If it is said to have taken twelve or thirteen days, it must have descended to the western provinces.

translation: "After that, although he felt affection, he did not ask any further questions."

original: 「此少き者を今一度見ばや。」とこそ宣ひけれ。

original: 大納言一人にもかぎらず、警を蒙る輩多かりけり。

translation: The messenger from Fukuhara was to be sent out to Toba tonight.

translation: Placing the child on his knees, he combed and stroked his hair, and tears streamed down his face. "Alas, when you reach seven years of age, I had thought you would come to me as a man. But now there is no hope. If you live and grow up, become a monk and mourn for me in the afterlife," he said. Although the child was too young to understand, he nodded. Then the Lord of Tango, along with his mother, the nurse, and the women in attendance, whether they felt it or not, all wept.

original: 少將は今年三つに成給ふをさなき人を持給へり。
translation: The Lord of Tango had a child who was only three years old.

original: 女房達は、叶ざらん物故に、猶も唯宰相の申されよかしとぞ歎かれける。
translation: The ladies lamented, "Since this matter cannot be fulfilled, they still only sighed, hoping that the Minister of the Right would say something."

original: 宰相、「存る程の事は申つ。世を捨るより外は、今は何事をか申べき。されども縱何くの浦に坐すとも、我命の有ん限は、訪奉るべし。」とぞ宣ける。
translation: The Minister of the Right said, "I shall speak of the matter as it is. Other than abandoning the world, what else should I say now? However, even if I were to sit at any distant shore, I must still visit and pay homage to my fate."

original: と云ふ歌の心を以て、當國の名所阿古耶の松とは仰られ候か。
translation: The journey from Dazaifu to the capital by the red-clothed messenger is fixed at fifteen days.

original: 』と申ければ、さらばとて、實方中將も出羽國に越てこそ阿古耶の松をば見たりけれ。
translation: To say that something near is far is to imply that the Great Minister's place of exile is unknown to the person who is supposed to know it.

original: 兼康は宰相の還聞給はん所を恐れて、道すがらも樣々に痛り慰め奉る。

translation: The distance between the village of Shikabe in Bitchū and the village of Yuki in Bizen was only about fifty cho, so the Lord of Tango, thinking of the wind from that direction, summoned Masakazu and asked, "How far is it from here to the place where the Great Minister is being exiled to, the Yuki temple in Bitchū?"
